description:
Food was awesome.  Service was awesome.  Very attentive and prompt service.  

Ordered spring rolls, sizzling beef and shrimp, raw beef salad with shrimp chips, calamari, fried wings, garlic noodles, crab, and shaken beef.  EVERYTHING was DELICIOUS.  But the highlight of the evening was the crab.  Deliciousness caked on the crab. It was like crack.  And you can smell the butter on the garlic noodles.  Stopped taking pics after the crab came out because fingers were greased in all that goodness. 

Left the restaurant with a fat belly.  Can't wait to come back.
author: Abby T.

description:
So sad. La Vie was the go-to higher-end Vietnamese destination of the early 2000's. I've had many an awesome dinner party at this place and their crab was absolutely amazing! How the mighty have fallen!

So, basically, very little about our food experience stood out considering they still charge higher-end prices for what you can get for far cheaper and at least as good at many other places. Weordered for dishes, relatively standard Vietnamese fair, and nothing was particularly amazing. On the contrary, the servings were small and the food was underwhelming. For instance, we got green beans with pickles and fried tofu it felt like it had been smothered and soy sauce. No subtlety whatsoever. 

Granted, it wasn't bad. The food was clean and if I had paid a third less for it, I would've been satisfied. But with those prices, it feels like they're inviting a deeper level of discernment that they don't I'm merging all that glowingly from. 

Either they have a consistent following that is keeping them afloat or the Vietnamese mob is using the place as a front to launder their money. Regardless, cheers to their longevity. Unless they upgrade something soon, I fear they'll just be another great place in SF that only loves on in memory.
author: Mario T.

description:
Have been eating here for 30+ years.  I love the way the dishes are prepared.  The Beef Pho is the best I've ever had, and I have tried it at alot of Vietnamese resturants.  Great for lunch and dinner.  I always take extra dishes home with me because I no longer live in the city.  I ate here several times a week when I lived closer.  La Vie has a good following of regulars.  On my last visit I finally ordered the crab, and it was incredible.  It
Tasted fantastic, but it is messy so be sure to ask for s bib
author: Carol F.

description: What a gem! Lots of inexpensive great looking dishes on the menu. It was fun to watch the flaming beef and shrimp prepared at our table. So delicious. Served with very fresh rice wrap ingredients. Impressed with how ingenious the process, presentation and system they used. Unique. Flavors were heavenly. Next we had their signature roast crab. I am hard to impress - love PPQ crab. La Vie crab was amazing and stood apart from any crab dish i had before. Wonderful flavors, unique preparation again. The best in my book. We are coming back soon. The crab is pricey but we were stuffed with the most enjoyable Sat night date dinner! Service was warm, friendly & quick.
author: Brett K.

description: My favorite Vietnamese restaurant in SF for Crabs, Flaming Beef, Shrimp roll and more.
author: Kok bin A.

description:
If it's one restaurant you should eat at in SF this is the ONE!!! Order the La Vie special crab but cooked the original Vietnamese style otherwise it will end up too sweet. In addition to the crab, order the flaming beef and prawns, green beans and shaking beef.  You will have the best meal in SF!

I've been to this restaurant for 20 years and is much better than the other crab restaurant hands down! It's a family run restaurant and the service is very personable.  This restaurant has been under rated for so long.
author: Sheila S.

description:
eat here and you are risking your life.

I experienced severe food poisoning.  The SF Health Department confirmed several violations and counseled the owners to just pay my bill, since that was all that I asked.  They refused. 

The food is good but the kitchen was unsanitary. I hope this post prevents you from suffering as I did.
author: Ann R.

description: Everything was super fresh, creative, delicious and so unique. The combinations of such variety of flavors in each dish was amazing. I had the Buddah Noodle Salad...it was freakin delicious!!
author: Susie L.

description:
This place has been around forever and I remember coming here as a kid. Decided to go back and try this place again. Not busy at all. Only one person working and cooking, but service was still good and the food was thumbs up. I was surprised. Everything was flavorful and cooked perfectly. 

The raw beef and chips had great flavors. Not the usual beef carpaccio I'm use to, but I like the way they did theirs. 

The lotus root salad-this wasn't bad, but I had better.

From Yelpers, the flaming beef and shrimp is a must get-Served table side and the bowl is in flames while the beef and shrimp is cooking. Comes with rice paper to wrap. Super good. Small portions on this, but this was one of my favorites.

Garlic crab with garlic noodles-great garlic flavors and the roe of the head, they make it into this butter sauce that you can add to your crab and garlic noodles. 

Pork Skewers-super tender and flavorful. Lots of meat. 

Will be back!
author: Karen H.

description: Excellent restaurant. Was a little put off at first sine we were the only customers at 7:15pm on s Saturday night, but the place started filling up soon after. Food & Service amazing
author: Ed L.

description:
This is not a traditional Vietnamese restaurant definitely more upscale, dark romantic setting.  My favorite restaurant in the Bay Area. 
The salad was fresh and light very refreshing ! 
The crab dishes are  to die for since my visit I've attempted to recreate the dish over and over. (I'm getting better) but their crab dish blows mine out of the water. 
Garlic noodle was a pleasant surprised I was expecting rice white. They had a really cool dish with fire I don't remember the name! 

It is on the pricey side for a Vietnamese restaurant but worth every penny!
author: Lauren N.

description: Last minute change of plans led us to La Vie and I'm glad. Food was great and the lady who tended to us was fantastic! Give it a try
author: This Is M E.

description: Best pho in Northern California and don't argue with me :). Friendly husband (front of house) and wife (back of house) team. I rarely deviate from the pho, but everything we've tried has been delicious. Only downside is they close a couple months a year to visit family. I see some reviews noting terrible service, but I've never had an issue. It's usually just one person serving, so you need to be patient. Worth the wait though, I promise.
author: Olivia T.

description: Ate dinner here. Lemon grass chicken and cat fish soup with rice. I thought food was okay but portions were a little small. We had an appointment after dinner so didn't want to chance ordering additional entree. Also the reason we didn't order the roast crab that was their specialty.  Nice decor relatively clean looking seating. Street parking a little tight in this neighborhood
author: Clifford W.

description: Came here with a group of 12. Service was prompt and attentive. Food was excellent but the highlight of the night was the Crab with Garlic Noodles. This was hands down the best crab dish I've ever had! Better than my friend's Mom's crab...
author: Joel A.

description:
Incredibly small portions and terrible service bring this place down to two stars from what would easily be a 4 star review based on the flavor alone. I've been eating here for over 20 years. The flaming prawns and beef cooked tables idea is delicious, but at $15.95 you'd expect more than 3 shrimp and maybe 25 grams of beef. The Bo Luc Luc is the best I've ever tried, again very small portion. 

Lastly, consult your check if the older woman is your server, in the last few years she has "accidentally" overcharged  $1 here and $1 there, then pretends it's just a mistake.
author: Hank S.

description:
We live nearby so we wanted to try this place as it seemed like a nice little spot.  Food actually tastes good. BUT, as other reviews state, the portions are very small AND the service is complete crap.  In that sense, I would also consider this place WAY  overpriced.  We ordered the cubed steak dish and I think we got 6-7 tiny pieces of meat and a bunch of onions. 

If you're into this cuisine (garlic noodles/crab), both quality/portions and service are MUCH better at PPQ (which is right around the corner on Clement St). Prices are about the same but you're getting more bang for your buck and the service is significantly better. OR you can ball out ($$$$) and take yourself to Thanh Long in the sunset.
author: Matthew C.

description:
My new favorite Vietnamese restaurant!! I've been here three times this past month. Needless to say, I'm obsessed! 

The Banh Xeo is absolutely amazing. This is the dish that brings me back every single time. The crepe is made better than any other place I've tried in California. Super duper crispy! Even when it gets cold. I ordered two to share last time. 

The Shrimp Cupcake is also amazing. The waiter recommended it and raved about how much I'd like it if I liked the Banh Xeo so much. He was right! Really similar in the how they add a variety of fresh side ingredient and the cupcake is so cute! It's made with mung bean I believe and the shrimp flavor is just delicious. Apparently it takes a lot of work to make this dish so the chef only takes the order if it's not too busy. 

The Flaming Beef is awesome. It literally is flaming! And you get to watch it on fire for quite a few minutes. It's cooked with a mix of tomatoes and onions that are sooo flavorful. Comes with really good quality rice paper too. And they have the rice paper prepared and separated on these special plates to keep it moist. 

The salads are all solid. They kind of all taste the same, but I don't mind. I've had the Shrimp Salad and the Lotus Root Salad. Both taste really refreshing. They add this fried crispy noodle thing on top for a nice crunch that also looks super cute. 

Quail was also yummy and flavorful. It was a special and came with 2 quails. Not something I would order again though. 

Garlic Noodles are the only mediocre entree I've had here. Really simple boxed spaghetti noodles in a forgettable creamy garlic sauce. I'm sure it'd taste better eaten with the crab though. 

But overall, the star of the show is the waiter! He runs the whole place and is a hoot. Loves telling stories about his soon to be doctor daughter and how he spoils her. He also makes great food recommendations!

Next time, I'm gonna save up for the famous crab! Was $64 last I checked but apparently enough to share among two people. Still really pricey though but I want to try it!
author: Carolyn L.

description:
I consider this place a hidden gem. It's not just because Hanson is the coolest waiter around who happens to be a bigger sports nut than me, but the food speaks for itself and it's been consistent since my first bowl of piping hot Pho last year.

La Vie means Life in French, and I will go out on a limb and say their food is life-giving indeed.

Menu says vegetarian, but it's completely 100% VEGAN!!

Hanson told me they pride themselves on their vegetarian menu. They do not use eggs, fish sauce or dairy in their veg dishes. They just haven't gotten around to calling it vegan.

The only thing that is not on the vegetarian menu is the quintessential food of Vietnam, Pho. I asked Hanson how do you make this dish...he laughed and rolled his eyes. In his head he was probably saying, " I know it's good, but I'd be damned before I give you my secret!"

What to order:

I've tried almost everything on the menu, but some of the favorites that I come back to time and time again are the following:

Vegetarian Pho (It's vegan) - The broth is so flavorful that the ubiquitous condiments of hoisin and hot sauce were not needed to enhance the flavor. My taste buds were already going crazy with this life-giving vegetable broth. A few sprigs of basil, bean sprouts and a squeeze of lemon was all that was needed to take this Pho to great to the greatest!

Vegetarian Imperial Roll - These are made with rice paper and deep-fried and are pictured on your right. Every one has a different way of eating them, but follow suit and you will not be sorry. I take a lettuce leaf and tear it in half. Then I place a few cucumbers, a few carrots, rice noodle with peanuts, and put one imperial roll on the lettuce leaf. I then top off the Vietnamese style gluten-free wrap with mint, cilantro and their house made chili soy sauce. Roll it up like a wrap and enjoy!

Coconut Curry Eggplant -  The coconut curry was delicious and decadent. A side of steamed rice was perfect to cut the richness a tad. The eggplant was soft and delicate and simply melted as I took a bite.

It was hard to describe the party that was going on in my mouth at the time. Needles to say I was in vegan food heaven.

Green Bean with Radish - These aren't your grandmothers green beans. They are infused with soy and garlic and cooked to perfection because they have that beautiful crisp that I am fond of with the green bean yet retained so much flavor without compromising the integrity of the vegetable. 

These are some initial recommendations, but you can't go wrong with anything on the vegetarian menu (which is actually vegan menu).

Well there you have it. Another San Francisco restaurant with great options for the meatless folks.

Cheers to good eats,

Anand
author: Anand S.

description:
Restaurant is located in the outer Richmond and is easily missed. A wonderful ambiance that is warm and comfortable. Great place for large parties, romantic date night, or a quiet evening enjoying a good meal.
Beef ceviche was light and refreshing with a burst of flavor and zest. Served with onions, cucumbers, cilantro, carrots, nuts with a hint of mint. 
Coconut curry eggplant. Be careful as they serve this dish garnished with nuts. Sweet and chunky. Aromatic with a creamy taste and texture. A fulfilling dish.
Vegetarian crepe was crunchy but my preference was for a bit more softness. It was filled with bean sprouts and mushroom. Wrap with lettuce and dipped into the sauce, yummy.
Vegetarian hot and sour soup is delicately spicy. It is filled with chunks of tomatoes, tofu, bean sprouts, celery, spices, and pineapple. Sweet and savory. This soup is filling and delightful.
Overall, a good experience at a place with good food. Enjoy this nice sit down white table cloth Vietnamese restaurant.
author: David H.

description: Ok. Confirmed that the service is terrible here! Slow, indifferent service. The food was good, but portions were very small. We got 7 dishes plus rice for 5 people and it was just enough. The food was good. Beef cubes had great flavor but was super puny. Mostly onions and maybe 6 little cubes of meat. Was almost embarrassing to have to try to share such dinky portions. Catfish flavor was good. Five spice chicken was good. Seriously the service was just the worst part.
author: Kris F.

description: $70 for a Crab??? WTF  And the lady put the tip in our bill... lol she gives her self a tip with my credit card!!! She call 911 because we refuse to pay what she was asking.
author: Ron J.

description: Love this place but why is it always closed when it says it's supposed to be open! Has happened at least 4 times now
author: Bobs S.

description: The food was really delicious, however the service was terrible! The kicker was receiving our bill and being over charged for we had  ordered....  Wish I'd read previous reviews before dining there. Shame shame shame. Zero stars for sure.
author: steph b.

description:
The best Vietnamese restaurant in town the first time I came here I order the La vie roast crab and the La vie beef it was so good , that I came back 4 times in 1 month the waiter were so nice the food came out hot not warm . The food was very fresh,they season it just right. The first bite just melt in your mouth.

Linda
author: Linda J.

description:
"That did not suck," my lunch mate said. 

In fact, everything was fresh, including the house-made sauces, unlike the popular sriracha sauce that used to say "no preservatives" but now adds polysorbate 80 and potassium sorbate. Those now-mass-produced bottles do not deck the tables here. 

Jazz playing over the sound system is a refreshing change from the pop noise that pollutes the 1000-4000kHz sound range in many other Asian restaurants. 

We were there for a quiet Saturday lunch. The lights were dim, not over-bright, but enough to see the food with the natural light coming from the south-facing window. The lighting made the place look closed from outside. Glad to find the door open. We sat by the window and people-watched through the huge single pane of sadly-scratchittied glass. 

The spring rolls were atypical. No peanut sauce. But delicious. The pho was well-seasoned, and helped my MCS cough subside. Best pho yet, imo. The calamari is a must-order with fresh peppers, bell and hot, and smattering of other greens including cabbage accompanied by a fresh, spicy no-preservative dipping sauce.  We saved the leftover sauce for the rest of our meal. 

Then there are the details like carrot slivers in the soy dipping sauce and thin sliced green onions in the beef pho side serving. Nice touches make a difference. 

How did I miss this place in a year of living in Outer Richmond? It didn't matter that there was only one other occupied table. The roughed up window became forgotten as dish after dish livened our taste buds with flavor neither over-salted nor over-sweetened. Everything was delicious and fresh. What a hidden gem in the Richmond. We will most definitely be back.
author: Kiai K.

description:
On Saturday night a group of 14 friends dined at La Vie. When we arrived they had our table set up and were accommodating. There were only two servers in the whole restaurant but luckily the restaurant was actually slow. We had the following dishes:

La Vie Roasted Crab 5/5 stars excellent, kind of tamarind sweet savory taste.

Garlic Noodles            5/5 stars goes great with the roasted crab sauce bits

Shrimp spring rolls    4/5 stars good but normal Vietnamese spring rolls

Flaming Beef               4/5 stars thin slices of beef with bowls lit on fire wrapped with 
                                                        veggies in rice paper rolls, lots of show, little volume

Pork chops                   2/5 stars very sweet and salty. 

Coconut Penna Cotta 4/5 stars smooth, creamy.

The food was good. The restaurant is small but many of the dishes are showy and require the servers to cook or light on fire. And with only two servers dinner was 4 hours but with good friends that's OK. Bad was the air conditioning and the ventilation. The heat was like outside in Saigon in the middle of summer. Bill including tip $920.
author: George F.

description:
Terrible experience. When my bill would only come to about $18 they told me they wouldn't accept a credit card* and that I had to either: (1) pay with cash or, (2) get out. 

Who's surprised I left? 

And guess who will -never- go back?

I live in this neighborhood, and I eat out 3-5 times a week. Was that really a smart idea? No. No it wasn't. 


* There is no sign saying there is a CC minimum.
author: Cori N.

description:
Their portions are tiny. They skimp on ingredients. They sliced the shrimp lengthwise so it would look like they put more in than they actually do. By the way the prices on the Yelp menu are nowhere near accurate. You'll pay 50-150% more than listed here. I wouldn't mind the prices as much if the portions were at least decent. If you're calling an order I recommend you ask the prices first so you have an idea.
The sad thing is the food is pretty good and they are very close to me, but I don't think I'll be back anytime soon. Maybe they just don't like call in orders judging by the (mostly) positive reviews here.
author: Stephen C.

description: I visited this restaurant for lunch on a quiet day in the dining room which may account for the very nice and prompt service and pleasant waiter. The curry chicken was boring and featured an uninspiring broth...sorry, there is much better close by.
author: Dick J.

description: Oh my God I love the food here so much, The perfect taste, specially the roasted crabs with garlic noodle, nowhere can't comparing, I would love to go back and celebrate my birthday party here, with all of my friends...
author: Kim T.

description:
Even with a short staff, food and service was excellent .
Garlic noodles and la vie crab was out of this world. The price is worth the experience. The green beans were an added must accompaniment.
author: Monica R.

description: Best pho I've had in the city. It's a quaint sit down place, so not your hole-in-the-wall kind of pho- but the soup is incredibly tasteful and so Rich in flavor. (There is nothing worse than a bland pho) I love bringing people here to give them a taste of the best pho I've had in sf. I also like that the place is nicely cared for and quiet. The family is also very kind, and I've only had great interactions with them. I've only had the chicken and beef pho here with appetizers. It's so good, I never could get myself to order something else. Try for yourself!
author: Grace L.

description: Terrible place!! They charge for things that you didn't order or they charge more and don't tell you, if you don't pay attention you will pay much more! I'll never go back there anymore! I recused to pay what they were charging me and they call the cops, once the cops were there the cops says that they weren't right to do that, they added the tip on my bill before I even decided to give them tip or not! At the end the cops explained to them that they cannot do that with anyone.
author: Marco F.

description:
Excellent food and service
The crepe, the seafood nest, soft shell crabs and of course the garlic crab! Every dish was well spiced and well prepared. Loved the combination of crab with garlic noodles!
Will come back again! Thank you
author: Liz M.

description:
We had a party here on January 1 for my mom's birthday. With 24 of us (half are kids), we pretty much had the restaurant to ourselves. I pre-ordered the food in advance to save the headaches. The owner was friendly and willing to work with me on the menu at a budget. 

Overall, I thought the food was great although some would beg to differ. A few dishes were way too salty. The biggest complaint was the portions of each dish. I was quite disappointed to see such small portions served given the price they charge. We kept ordering more and more (on top of what we pre-ordered) up until we realized there was no point because the portions were so tiny. With a bill goes to $900, some of us still had to go home to fix up a bowl of instant noodles.

Lesson learned: this is not your place for big parties.
author: Em T.

description:
This is my favorite vietnamese restaurant in the city.  

Service is always amazing.  The food is great because: 1. Nuoc Mam (fish sauce) is perfectly balanced: it's not too watered down and not too sweet like most other restaurants in the city. 2. They have Flaming Beef and Prawns!  It's served in a porcelain bowl, cooked at your table and you wrap it up in the rice paper.  I've had variations on this dish many times before, but for some reason it took me 15 years to find it in San Francisco.   You can't come here and NOT order this. 3. The La Vie Roast Crab is also wonderful.
author: Megan M.

description:
Remember when we booked out the whole place at Playground? This one ajumma got so jinroed that she not only reached over and bibimed my bap but then proceeded to spoon-feed me. The entire interlude was #wth #facepalm #isthisreallyhappening #yesitis.

La Vie (thankfully) didn't get to that point, but things were certainly toeing the line. With the server randomly hovering and reaching in to roll my beef and glove my hands, picking up my food and holding it for me to bite was the server's unspoken next step.

DRUNKEN QUAIL $13.95: Good. Leave nothing behind but the plate.
photo http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=86MUsF43sZ6CI1RkQ5CEUw&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA

BEEF FONDUE IN VINEGAR $14.95: DIY tableside. So fresh (and so clean) tasting.
photo http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fohGfg-6vql0ORu4RpWFUQ&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA

FIVE SPICED ROAST CHICKEN $9.95: Okay. Skin wasn't crispy like we'd hoped. Boneless.
photo http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=q_xyYm0ZJDza4VKuHbNRmQ&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA

LEMON GRASS RICE NOODLE $9.95: Had some zing, but not spicy-spicy.
photo http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=07bdyGwLDT2dmFVet86H-A&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA

CHICKEN FRIED RICE $10.95: Straightforward. It was rice that was fried.
stand-in photo http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=CB-IEplIf5MfP6vIh1AkxQ&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA

PASSION FRUIT ICE TEA $2.95: Generous portion. Fruit infusion wasn't overpowering.
photo http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=7j22DVqc0naoDePsy2GFKg&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA

I will be back for the Caramel Catfish Claypot, Cherimoya Shake, assorted crab specialties, other things... basically a good chunk of the menu. Rating-wise, closer to 3 1/2 than 3.
author: Dan B.

description: This is my absolute favorite place to get pho. It's so delicious and clean tasting, not too greasy like other places. I've tried other dishes here while my mom was in town, but the star of the show is the pho. The waiter is super nice and attentive as well, tho it can be awkward if no one else is there. Seriously, the pho is amazing and that is all you need to eat here!! Delicious!
author: Kasey M.

description:
Instead of writing a long story, here are the highlights:

Very slow service (we are a party of 15), plus other tables and one waiter.
Dishes are extremely salty.
Portions are small.
The items are not cheap.  It came to $495.00, still not enough to satisfy.

Here's the worst:  A mandatory 20% tip added on the bill, AND based on the total plus tax, which means we had to pay a tip on the sales tax.
When we complained about the tip, the owner agreed and re-calculated based on food total only, but still a 20% tip !!!

One star is given to a clean restroom.
author: Gary Y.

description:
A great spot for clean eating, a peaceful atmosphere, a kind staff, and good vibes. La Vie gets a 10 out of 10. 

While looking for Pho last night (a San Francisco cliché?) I stopped into a Vietnamese restaurant only to find chicken and pork Pho, which I don't eat. Refusing to be discouraged I tried the next spot on Geary, called La Vie, and I was immediately impressed by how clean, pleasant, and quiet it was- With soft lighting, and an aesthetic set up. 

I asked the hostess/server if they had vegetarian Pho. She said yes, and to my surprise she offered a secret menu with vegan Pho, if that was of interest! I became excited! I ordered takeout for myself and my boyfriend who was sick. 

While waiting, curious about this new place I'd found, I looked over at what others in the restaurant were eating. I noticed that everything appeared to be exceptionally fresh and high quality in this quiet and beautifully lit Vietnamese restaurant. Then and there I decided I wanted to return to try something new. I had a good feeling about this place. 

Thirty minutes later I sat in my boyfriend's living room eating my vegan Pho. I can say without reservation, it was the best Pho I've had in San Francisco. The vegetables had flavor, the noodles were soft and fresh, and the vegetable broth and tofu were delicious- And I can't wait to go back again to try something else. Additionally, I need to communicate how helpful, kind, and patient the hostess/server was. Her presence added to the good vibes of the restaurant.

La Vie, thanks for the Pho!
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Seafood soup has two shrimps in it...
No no place to have seafood... but service is good. And place has no wait line.  No wonder why.
author: Val G.

description: My husband and I had our 2nd date here about ~16 months ago. We frequent this place for their great food and service. It was only appropriate that we eat our first lunch as Mr & Mrs here today! Never fails great food and great memories... Try the spicy lemon grass beef (or chicken or shrimp), delicious. My husband had his favorite PHO, he refuses to eat it anywhere else!
author: Caring C.

description:
La Vie is one of the three restaurants my family and I go to when everyone is at home or for special occasions - we travel an hour to eat here!  It is a family-run restaurant, and they always recognize us and ask how we have been doing.  The main waiter there is funny, he does 'magic tricks' for us that crack us up.  
Their specialty - the La Vie Roast Crab - is SO DELICIOUS!!  They bring the crab out but take off the main shell once served and underneath is the most delicious crab mixed with garlic and I don't know what, but the crab legs are soo good too - it's not just ordinary crab, but its so flavorful.  We always order two for a family of 5 and it also comes with a side of the garlic noodles.  They bring out lemon bowls afterwards because it can get messy.  We always get the La Vie Combo (which you make your own rolls with grilled prawns, beef, rice noodle, a crispy spring roll, pickled carrots/daikon and rice paper), Sizzling Rice Soup, Beef Look Luck, Seafood Crispy Egg Nest, Crisp Salt and Pepper Wings (the most delicious, crispy wings topped with a jalapeno/red pepper and a spicy fish sauce on the side), House Fried Rice (this isn't greasy or heavy like Chinese fried rice can be, it is light and really good)  We always get Vietnamese drip coffee (individually drips into your coffee cup - DON'T stir it! You have to be patient for this...it has condensed milk on the bottom and the coffee is very strong).  The waitress knows my family, and we always order the Mango Panna Cotta - she tells us to call beforehand to make sure there are enough or else she would make them for us!  The Fried Banana and Ice Cream is pretty good too

La Vie will always be the restaurant we go to for special occasions - the food is so delicious (I haven't tried my pho here, but my parents have and say it is the best pho they have had).  They tell us they travel around and taste different things to try to improve their menu, but the flavors of every dish is spot on - I recently moved to NYC and dream about their food, but I'll be back in a few months and will definitely come back here! :)
author: Risa H.

description:
First time to La Vie and I was impressed with many things. I will get into that but I don't want you to think that I had this huge meal with a lot of variety. I had pho. It was a cold day so what better that a nice hot bowl of the this fine countries soup offering. 

I really liked the pho. the broth was robust in flavor, the noodle to broth distribution good. If this was a quick pho joint the bowl would probably be considered a small but the flavor of this place was above what you may have experienced at the aforementioned locales. The meatballs were ok. The beef was really good- I wanted more and feel it wasn't enough. I'm hoping it was due to better quality meat being used than other places I've been to. Overall a good bowl of pho. 

The place is unite clean and the service by one waitress was spot on for a Tuesday afternoon. I feel if there were a table or two more they would definitely need more waitresses. 

Price was reasonable as I mentioned at other places the bowl would be considered a small but that is ok. 

A couple of side notes- one of their menu prices said $1,95 when I asked the waitress she said it was supposed to read $11,95. Big difference which should be fixed. 

Also there is a $2 charge if you use a credit card for purchases under $18. That seems a little exorbitant. I rarely carry cash so I may decide upon another place if I am craving pho. Sad really. 

Overall I will come back but hopefully with cash in hand or more of an appetite.
author: Angel G.

description: My partner and I went to this restaurant because Turtle Tower was too crowded. I really liked the menu options. They have more options than Turtle Tower and more dishes. I liked that they had a vegetarian imperial roll and the atmosphere is more romantic. The waitress was incredibly helpful and made sure I was happy with the dish I got. I recommend it.
author: Anne F.

description:
Hard to warrant a higher average rating in the Richmond district in San Francisco - with all the selection available in this area.

I honestly only came here because Turtle Tower was closed already. I was in the mood for Pho Ga / Chicken Noodle Soup and La Vie was still open.

Had an order of their fried calamari - pretty flavorful, only downfall is that the quantity of squid was pretty low... finished this appetizer rather quickly. 

Their chicken noodle soup was surprisingly really good. Being a fan of Turtle Tower's pho ga, I didn't expect the bowl here could have been in the same conversation.

Friendly staff... another thing that may hurt this place is the turnaround time for food. It felt like we waited for quite some time for the noodles to come out...
author: Sam K.

description:
This was on my "to try" list in the neighborhood.

BUT tonight on the walk home my 4 year old urgently needed a bathroom.  I went in to ask if we could buy something and use the restroom but were told only a full sit down.  In 7 years of being a parent I've never seen a little one rejected during an emergency.  Instead we had to go in the bushes across the street.

Thanks La Vie.  Bookmark removed.
author: Kevin F.

description:
I was excited to come here since I am in the area a lot.  Vietnamese food is arguably one of my favorite asian cuisines and I have worked in Hong Kong for the last 3 years and traveled to almost every country in Asia at this point.  

It was one of those crazy work weeks and I came here on a Thursday night, there were about 7 tables of 2 people each that night and I was by myself.  I just wanted something quiet and good.  I sat down and looked at the menu for a while, the curry sounded good which was a combo of chicken and vegetables.  I asked if it came with rice which it did not so I ordered a side of brown rice.

The place was quiet and relaxing.  My food came out and I took a few bites and just didn't really like it.  I was kind of bummed and figured I would just power through it and leave and not enjoy my downtime.  Then after a total of 5-6 bites after spitting out some of the chicken because of lower quality cuts I decided why should I put myself through this?  It isn't a healthy dish, it isn't good and I want to find a new go to place for vietnamese food.

It was about $11-$12 which is pretty reasonable but I still wanted to be able to eat it.  I asked her when she walked by if I could get something else because I didn't like it.  I almost never do this, maybe a total of 2-3 times (including this one) in my life but I really couldn't eat it.  It was brown curry that was sweet, thick and reminded a bit of wet dog food or economy plane food on an American carrier.  The vegetables were fine, it was the sauce and the chicken that I really couldn't eat.

After I quietly asked to get something else, she said why?  I explained I really didn't like it and would just order something that wasn't chicken and did not have this sauce.  She said well you already ate half of it.  I responded I did not, I had about 5 bites, maybe 6.  2 pieces of chicken, 1 celery sliver, 1 broccoli and maybe 1 other vegetable bite and I just had to put the chicken bits with the tendons on the side of my plate.  She said, that she has never heard of anyone doing such a thing and just doesn't know what to do.  I said go mention it to the chef and let me order something else.  I will keep my rice for the next dish.  She said ok be right back.

She then proceeded to check on every single table asking if they liked their food.  I noticed 1 other person who ordered to curry who didn't eat much of it.  The server asked how it was and why she didn't finish it and the customer responded "she was full".  I unfortunately heard my rude server asking anyone as she did it loud enough so I could hear.  I felt this was quite catty and very unprofessional and made me feel uncomfortable.   I overheard her, not by choice, just because she was asking everyone how their food was loud enough so I had to hear, about how their meal was and everyone said it was good.  

So she came back to me with a lot of attitude and said I just asked everyone in the restaurant how their curry was they liked it so you are wrong.  She said I can't help you since everyone else liked it.  The thing here is I only hear and saw 1 other person eat the curry who didn't finish it.  Maybe it was because she was full or that she prefers to avoid eating dog food, who knows? No one else that I could see had this curry.

AND even if they had, is that really the way to handle this?  Ask everyone else to prove me wrong?

She came back and said we can't take that off your bill.  She said that I am only doing this because it is an Asian restaurant.  That no one does this in American places and insinuated I was racist.  I said no, actually it has nothing to do with it being Asian, it just isn't good and I would like something else.  She continued to raise her voice at me and said that I can't just expect free food and she doesn't have to do anything about this dish.  I should just pay for it and leave.  For some reason I was still calm and nice and I said but I was looking for a local go to vietnamese place I could eat at.  She said well don't come back.  I said why are you making this such a big deal?  And she said I am directing this here because it is an Asian restaurant.  I finally said ok, well then I am just going to leave then and walked out.

I honestly feel like I have never had a more rude server in my life.  She was pretty awful and I promise, it has nothing to do with the place being Asia, I love Asian food.  She was very immature and unprofessional.  I will obviously never come back since the food wasn't good, the service was terrible and apparently I am not welcome back either.  The whole time I was very quiet, polite and calm.  I just wanted something edible.
author: Alexis B.

description: Service was very nice, atmosphere was mediocre.  Pho was more expensive than new York,  almost $10 for bowl.  Broth was very flavorful, not much meat, no tripe which was my favorite. Chicken roll was pretty good
author: esther h.

description:
Worst whole crab experience I've had.  salt and pepper crab over fried to the point you can crack the shell body with your hands??? WTF.  This caused the delicious tamale to be dry.  Garlic noodles were cheesy and wet, overcooked/soft as well.  Sad and the worst came when the bill said $56, yes 5, 6 for the crab alone.  Do they think they're PPQ, Thanh Long, Crustacean's or R&G?  Really?  R&G is known for their consistent excellent crab and its around $40.  I think PPQ was only $36 the last time I went.  Totally out of control with the price and the outcome.  

Pho broth was clean.  Bean sprouts on the side were old.

Banh hoi with pork meatballs were tiny.

Veggie fresh spring rolls were whatever.

Its all Turtle Tower's fault for remodeling that we walked into here.  

Lived in SF my whole life, knew about this place for years.  Never tried it until my new coworker friend said he likes it.

Banh hoi at any Vung Tau, San Jose - see the difference.

Yummy yummy - 5 spice chicken
author: Kevin L.

description:
I live 6 blocks away from this restorant and during last 10 years visited this restorant . All food are in this La Vie restorant amazing !!!!
All kind of meal like Art ! Delicious ! They cook with all them soul and heart ! 
I visited them with my friends    And alway all my friend was exited and start to visit this restorant with them family too . No Line ! Always this place has tables ! 
La Vie crab is best crab I ever eat ! They do also meat and vegetables on a open Fire - Just front of your table ! And you may see this great performance  of food cooking during time your party .with friends ! 
They have the best warmest customer service that  I ever met in restaurants  
Also ones in my multiply visits in end of the course  they complimentary 
put on a table Ice cream  - I was very exited for this kindness from La Vie restorant . 
Defiantly I will continue visit this great restorant La Vie  and will Reccomend for all  other people to visit even at ones this restorant then after you try you continue visit this place always !
author: Marina S.

description:
Came here with my fiancé because this was the only restaurant opened for lunch that serves crab & one of our friends suggested it was good. 

We ordered a roasted salt & pepper dungeness crab that came with a side of garlic noodles. The roasted crab came out over seasoned. The garlic noodles was the worst dish. We figured why it was included with a crab order! It was prepared with overcooked spaghetti noodles instead of egg noodles. The noodles should have been mixed with garlic and Parmesan cheese instead it was sprinkled on top. We also ordered a sautéed string beans dish that was also salty and peppery! 

Besides the overpriced, crabby disappointment, the service was good.

Do not dine here if you want to experience a delectable crab + garlic noodle meal. You will leave here emptied wallet & dissatisfied. So far, nothing beats PPQ Dungeness & Thang Long in SF!
author: Hue C.

description:
great family run spot. might be a little pricier than most Vietnamese places but the menu has much more variety than the standard pho and rice plates you can find anywhere in the richmond. we liked it so much we went twice in a week. 

flavorful chicken pho and tomato noodle soup. spring rolls were solid. we've also tried the shaking beef, catfish clay pot and veggie nest. yum yum!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Delicious food! We ordered sea food noodle soup which was THE BEST! Other dishes were good as well. Very nice ambiance and the place is very clean. 
I gave 4 stars because they are understaffed - one waitress who was also helping in the kitchen.
author: Yana A.

description:
The place it self is pretty clean and standard with good service so I'll give it 4 stars 

But the food it'll be 5 stars ! 

I had a sea food noodle pho and its was one of the best that I had so far !

I will be back here for sure .
author: Alex B.

description:
Food:  Pho was fresh, delicious, and fast  
Staff:  super friendly and nice. 
Cleanliness:  Cleanest Vietnamese restaurant in SF.
Parking:  street parking.  it's all about luck.
author: Ann R.

description:
Three and a half stars only?! You must be kidding me.

I came here last Saturday with my family and enjoyed every moment of it. We ordered beef pho, chicken pho, flaming beef, five spices chicken, garlic noodles, and I think a couple more things but I didn't order so I wouldn't know. HAHA.

I had a sip of my sister's Vietnamese coffee which was extremely potent and full of kicking coffee.

I enjoyed the flaming beef the most, plus you get to watch the beef flame up on a dish of fire and oil. Wrapping it up in the rice paper was best because I usually don't put a lot of effort into eating. But they made wrapping your food in rice paper a lot easier by pre-wetting it for you and putting it on plastic nets to separate each paper.

Oh man, I'd definitely come back for more. Oh La Vie.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Super nice staff and quick pick up time. The Pho was really great and authentic, I just wish they delivered. 

Oh and the door to the place is heavy, so make sure not to trust the large Eastern European man who walks in ahead of you to hold the door for you. He's not big on niceties. I hope they spat in his soup, but I suspect they're too nice for all that. I'm not, so I stuffed shrimp rolls in his gas tank.
author: Adam B.

description: Stopped by for a late dinner. I ordered the beef pho and my boyfriend ordered the chicken pho. Have to say it was by far the best pho I've had in San Francisco! Definitely recommend this place!
author: Stephanie C.

description: This is the worst Vietnamese restaurant I had ever ate.  The food was ok, the service was just terrible n horrible.  It's the old couple that's operating the restaurant, maybe the owners?  They were in such a rush to throw us out by cleaning our plates out from our table without asking us when we were still eating.  I even gave them20% tips on top of that.  Freaken rude people, worst viet people I had ever dealt with in 40 years eating Vietnamese food. Top the rude service of the year n it's barely August.  Lol
author: James C.

description: This place is not the place to go to. Service is Slow. The server took to long to bring the sauces. I ordered Passion Fruit Ice Tea and I got Lipton Ice Tea and when I mentioned it to the waiter he brought the whole jug to "show me that is was infact passion fruit tea" I could see the tea bags in there. The soups needed flavor to bland. I wouldn't give them a 2nd chance.
author: M R.

description: This is a fantastic Vietnamese restaurant!  We were on the hunt for dungeness crab during our short stint in San Francisco in April.  We originally went to PPQ Dungeness and they were closed 40 minutes prior to when their hours stated, which really bummed me out.  But then we found La Vie!  We had the salt and pepper whole dungeness with garlic noodles and the house fried rice.  Everything was cooked perfectly and super flavorful.  Beware, when we left the restaurant our Uber driver told us we reeked of garlic but it was soooooo worth it!
author: Danielle U.

description:
The restaurant has nice ambience with decent service, and that's about it.

Experience: Poor
We were not given shirarcha like the other tables, and had to ask for it.

Food: Disappointing
Do not order the garlic noodle. Do not order the pan fried noodle, because if I can make it better that really means the noodle was...disappointing.

Price: a pretty penny for the experience and food.
author: Liz N.

description:
First time at this place and it was great!  Food is probably the best Vietnamese fusion cuisine I've had ever...will definitely have to come back just to eat here.  We ordered the steamed sea bass, roasted garlic Dungeness crab, garlic noodles, black bean green beans, calamari salad, the lotus salad, and the sweet and sour catfish soup.  All of it was delish and the taste was very well balanced.  The dishes came out a lil longer than usual but the quality of food was really worth the wait. 

My belly is full!  Oy
author: Lala Y.

description: I eat a lot of Pho in the city and everywhere I go. This place is awesome. One of the few places with five spice chicken in the broth or bbq pork. Both highly recommended. The broth is a tiny bit fattier than I'd like, but I'm a little averse to any fats.
author: Dan T.

description:
Great food. Even better service.

Food first. We had the beef pho and eggplant with garlic. Both tasty, well-seasoned, good quality and nicely portioned. I dislike restaurants with big portions and low quality food. This was the opposite.

Service. Amazing! Hansen not only kindly offered to help me with a personal issue I had, he escorted my elderly companion to the curb while I went to get my car to pick up my companion. Thank you Hansen! We'll be back soon!
author: Terry Y.

description:
OK - when you go out to an Asian restaurant you expect fast service in and out...but come on... about 90 minutes for Vietnamese food.  This is actual time sitting at a table and not waiting to be seated.

If I could, I would give 0 stars

Here is the rough the timeline:
Seated immediately - got the menu
15 minutes from seated to when our order was taken
20 minutes from order taken to appetizer served
15 minutes from appetizer served to when main courses were served
20 minutes eating
15 minutes from when finished to when someone came to take 1 set of dishes
10 minutes from when we asked for the bill to when the bill came (had to ask twice)
Less then 1 minute to come pickup the cash - they were really fast doing this

When we there, the staff did not turn over tables or bus tables.  2 other couples came in waited to be acknowledge, but left since no one acknowledged them.  This place needs help in the front of the house to keep things flowing.

There were 2 people working the front and the place had less then a dozen tables, so there really should not be any reason why the staff could not keep up.  At no time during our dining did anyone come up and ask how were things or if we needed refills or anything at all.

The menus we received were old, looked like the same ones I saw about 10 years ago (yes - it has been that long since I ate here and I live only 7 blocks away.  Pages were dirty and ripped.  Changes/Additions were glued on to existing pages.

I ordered the Vietnamese iced coffee - when it came, I was happy it was served in the metal French Drip cup...however, when I opened the lid to press down on the press, I noticed the press was missing.  So I could not squeeze the grinds more then what a regular slow drip could do.  At least the coffee was good.  This was the best thing we ordered.

We ordered the Chicken Roll ($6.45) - flavor was decent, the mint added freshness to this dish; it did not need the accompanying dipping sauce.  The problem I had with the dish was the temperature...the outside part of the roll was room temperature and the inside of the roll was cooler.  The wrapper had begun to get hard again from sitting.

Five Spiced Roast Chicken Entree ($8.95) - the chicken was thickly cut and grilled.  Not too sure if the tamarind sauce was the dipping sauce or the chicken was marinated in to, but for a 5 spiced chicken, there was not much flavor.  However the pickled carrot garnish was pretty good.   The dipping sauce that came with the chicken was a combination of sweet chili sauce and I guess tamarind...it was watery and did not stick to the chicken.

Lastly we ordered the Tomato and Basil Noodle Soup ($8.95) - there is suppose to be ground shrimp and crab in this dish.  The soup base was lacking complexity you might expect from tomato and basil.  There was a tiny chiffonade of basil that did not add flavor or texture to the soup...it only added a bit of green to a basically red color broth.   Now the dish was suppose to only have shrimp and crab, but some how a mussel appeared in the dish...not sure what other dish shared either the same broth or noodles.


As my frequent followers know, I try to make it a point to review the bathrooms; on Facebook I photograph and collect different Men's room signs...I find variations funny, but this is the first time I felt I could not photograph or post a sign.  I cannot pin down which emotion I had when I first saw the sign...funny, troubled, disturbed or shocked.  

There were 2 gender neutral restrooms.  The one closet to the front is identified as being handicap accessible.  First of all, I have the say that both my wife and I went to the further one, the non handicapped.  I found that restroom clean and well lit.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The only issue I had about the room was the wall mounted soap dispenser...it was broken, but there was a pump dispenser on the sink.

Now for the signs on the doors: each door contained a sign that depicted a drawing of a male standing up with representation of pee coming out of his groin area.  For the women, there was a drawing of a female (I say crouched, my wife says squatting) with a pee being depicted coming from "the area".  

Overall my wife and I would come back to this place again.  They are in serious need of front of the house management and some sensitivity training or a better artist.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Finally a real Vietnamese restaurant offering a great quality food.
You have such a choice, for vegetarians included!
Dishes are simply delicious, very tasty.
Great service and very nice atmosphere. Love the deco too.
author: Florence O.

description: Food was good but shitty service. The server called me honey and ask extremely inappropriate questions. He blew me off when I tried to pay and told me to move and sit down.
author: Reiko n.

description:
I went here last night, for the first time,with friends and this place hands down had the best vegetarian Pho I've ever had. The broth was so perfect and full of flavor. Also, the fried rice was the best I've ever had! The guy who served us was really nice and talked to me about football cuz i was ele eating my Chargers shirt so I liked that he was warm and friendly like that too! So yah- I am officially in love with this place, and I can't wait to come back again... Maybe tonight? Haha. Definitely try this place.


Btw- I usually add peanut sauce to my broth at all places I go because the vegetarian broth tens to lack flavor. But I didn't even need to here! I still wound up adding a little just cuz I'm crazy about peanut sauce, but I enjoyed it just as much before I added it!
author: Apryl S.

description:
La Vie is my go-to for pho in the Richmond. Not only is it the only place outside of the Mission where I can find Vegan pho, but it's delicious. At 11 dollars a bowl, the price is a little steep, but the size is more than filling and the broth is killer. 

Another standout is the garlic eggplant. The sauce is ridiculously savory (and gluten free). The owners daughter (and manager) Sylvia is a great host. She's really friendly, remembers you after a single visit, is gluten-free and really knowledgeable about the menu. If the prices were even a smidge lower, it'd be 5 stars.
author: Sean F.

description: I've been here at least 5 times, and every time I really enjoy it. The owner is a wonderful man who always remembers us. The pho ga is always great, and every other dish I've tried has been wonderful too. One of my favorite restaurants in the Richmond District for sure. Highly recommend the five spice chicken and the lemongrass chicken!!
author: Kayla T.

description: Tasty carb, I ordered the spicy coconut carb. The tast very rich and delicious. Don't miss the desserts, I ordered the mango panna cotta, it taste very good.
author: Raging D.

description:
Food: A good alternative to PPQ. Ordered the soft shell crab and calamari appetizers and the tamarind and curry crab that came with garlic noodles. Everything was pretty good. The crab flavors were so different and really delicious.

Service: Needs improvement. There was only one waitress who took forever to take our order. When she finally did she hurried us and looked annoyed about our choices. When we realized how small of a portion the garlic noodles were and wanted to add another order she questioned us and almost seemed like she didn't want us to add on. She also seemed to be pouting and irritated slamming menus back in place and slamming the kitchen door. 

But overall the food was good and would come back.
author: Travis G.

description:
Decent but not fantastic food and incredibly slow service.

We ordered the raw beef salad, the sugarcane/shrimp wraps, and the claypot catfish. The sugarcane/shrimp wraps were DYI which was fun but sadly had much more lettuce than anything else (including herbs - these were just mint and cilantro). The sauce that came with it was delicious although mostly we felt like that the balance would have been better if the wraps had been pre-made. The raw beef salad was probably our favorite and had such potential but just needed a bit more lime and a lot more spice. The claypot catfish was actually the smallest dish of the meal despite being labeled as a entree. The fish was muddy tasting (being catfish) and came with a tasty but way too salty sauce. 

Overall the food was decent without anything that stood out. Possibly good enough to be 3.5 stars even. However, the service was pretty awful with only one waiter who ignored us and spent time clearing a group table despite the fact that we had been waiting for 10min already for our check.
author: Amy D.

description:
Oh, just the BEST pho gah I've had in SF, nbd. :) I absolutely love this place and don't recommend it just for the food, but the service and ambiance as well. 

Definitely wanna come back here, especially on dates.  So cute!
author: Mia F.

description: I have been here a few times an always enjoyed the food here. This place never fails. The food is delicious and beautifully presented. We tried an array of spring rolls, softshell crab, warm and hot noodles, spicy catfish. Hard to say which was my favorite! I loved them all. It is also a good place for groups so you can sample several dishes. Waitstaff were also helpful in choosing menu items. I have never tried the pho or other noodle soups, but might should I return with a smaller group. At a place like this, though, it seems a shame to be ordering soup when you could be enjoying other dishes. Downsides, well, as others have already indicated, service is slow and inattentive. The restaurant wasn't that busy (4 tables of customers?), but there seemed to be only one server. Most in our group were Asian, and there is that stereotype that Asians don't tip, or tip well enough, so our bill came with a 20% already included. I found that off putting and makes me hesitate to return, as much as I love the food. Why should I be required to tip (especially 20%, including tip on the tax) for subpar service? Maybe they won't add tip if I decide to do take out?
author: 和子

description:
The interior is really clean and presentable while their menu surprisingly entails many of the Vietnamese favorites from Banh Xeo to Chao Tom  as well as the simple Pho Tai.. I like it so far.. and they don't have an over inflated price on cafe sua da or Coke.. (+1)

That's just on the surface. But as far as how things turned out is concerned...

A)compared to anh huong, their banh hoi chao tom has a fuller sugarcane aroma throughout the plate than AH however in his establishment, they do give more veggies than vermicelli and shrimp, however the dish as still satisfying.  Wish it wasn't too dry as it came out. (-1)

Instead of being served with fish sauce, they give the peanut sauce ..its a nice change.

B) Banh Cuon  freshly made in house and cut to fair bite sized portions (+1)

C) Pho Tai - could use a little more flavoring in the broth,  so it wont seem too much like  boiled water (-1)

D) Coke was carbonated and not served flat... Waitresses also briught ice without having to be asked at all...what a lost art..(+1)

Those are the only plates i can speak of for now hehe..il be back
author: Eric C.

description: I would not suggest going to this restaurant if you are looking for authentic Vietnamese food. First off, it took five minutes for anyone to seat us even though the restaurant was almost empty. Also, the waitress did not take our order for a very long time until we finally got her attention. When the food did arrive, the curry we ordered was mostly just chili oil and vegetables. The meal was not appetizing and I was not happy with the service.
author: Shabina R.

description:
This was my second or third time having Pho. I had heard alot of nice things about this place from a friend and hence decided to go here for dinner. And I must say, this place lived upto my expectations.

We ordered the Chicken Soup Pho and the Vegetarian Pho, with a 100% vegetarian broth. I really like spicy food, so I asked them to make my Vegetarian Pho spicy.

I loved the flavor and the overall food preparation. The staff were courteous and friendly too and we had a great time overall. Definitely a place I am going to again!
author: Nitish S.

description: This is a nice local joint. Nothing to travel across neighborhoods for, unless you're in the area. I'm giving this 4 stars because it's a nice place for a local. If I was out of town, or out of the area maybe it'd get 3. I didn't find anything unappealing or repulsive, but I wasn't impressed. I enjoyed the lemongrass chicken and coconut noodles. It could've had more lemongrass but that's my opinion, it was still good. The place was quiet around 7, and worked up to half a full house by 8:30. There was only one hostess the whole time so managing us was fine but when it got busy I could see the anxious patrons growing impatient, waiting to order and waiting to be seated. It was an affordable delicious dinner nonetheless.
author: Elton F.

description:
A cab driver told my friends that this is his favorite Pho spot in the city and I completely disagree. Not only was the food bland but the service was absolutely awful. 

I came here on Sunday night with 2 of my friends and this place was not busy at all - maybe 8 other people dining here. We ordered the fresh shrimp rolls (tiny portion and barely any shrimp), veggie pho (that's what I had and it wasn't anything special), chicken pho and a chicken curry dish (this was the only decent thing that was brought out ((what my friends said - I don't eat meat)). 

I'm really not one to write a bad review unless the place really deserves it. The service that we had was so bad that it was funny! Both the older man waiter and the lady seemed as though not only did they hate their jobs but they truly hated us (and we weren't too needy and were very nice). When the lady brought out my friends Vietnamese Coffee and he simply opened it to look inside, she pretty much shoved his hand away from the glass. He's had Vietnamese Coffee before and knew exactly what he was doing! Not once did either of the waiters come to us to ask us how our meal was, but that's not even the best part... I asked for extra Cilantro for my pho (usually, all other places give you sprouts, basil, jalepenos, lemon AND cilantro - this place didn't). When I asked her for it, she told me there is already cilantro in my pho (there was BARELY any in it). I asked her if I can have a little more and it felt as though I was asking her for a star from the moon. When she returned with a plate full of cilantro (I asked for a little), we asked her to bring us some fresh onions. After asking that, she said in a very rude, almost screaming tone, "ANYTHING else?" We were in complete shock! We weren't asking for much, just a couple of things!

Here's the kicker... the bill comes and there's an extra $4.00 on the bill. When we asked what this bill was for, the waiter tells us its for the cilantro and onions. I'm sorry, but I have NEVER had any Vietnamese restaurant charge extra for cilantro and onions. Those are items that should come standard with any Pho! When I explained this to the waiter, he didn't care and all and told us we have to pay for it. I just laughed. What an experience! 

The food wasn't great and the service was AWFUL. Don't recommend this place!
author: Anastasia N.

description:
aye mama mia
flaming beef, pear sangria
no diarrhea
author: Wayne C.

description:
So torn, so hard to write anything negative because: It was Christmas Eve. The Waitress was working the whole restaurant ALONE. Yes, one server, lovely and doing 100% her best, and yet many, many hungry families. It was a hard scene to watch. 

The saving grace was our arrival at 6pm. By 730pm it was a painful scene. But I know this was a likely rare event. Any other day of the year is probably ok! 

The good: Food was good. But be WARNED: every dish was garlic served with a side of... vegetables, crab, etc. GARLIC GARLIC GARLIC. Now, if this is your thing, you're in heaven. For me, the after taste of garlic took days to shake. I was a walking garlic bulb for at least 24 hours. But that is my own fault-- you choose what you put in your mouth, right? So I can't fault La Vie for this. 

The ambience is romantic and clean. I am a fan. Just have to plan better and avoid the garlic more.
author: Kim D.

description:
The flaming beef is the yummiest and most interesting to watch it burn in flames! It came with the wraps and salad. Definitely a must order dish.

The garlic noodles are a-okay.

We came here sunday night, there was only a few restaurants that were open until 10pm n were not crowded. I asked my sister to call them and see if they will still accept us if we come in at 9.45 and they happily said yes. Their service is wonderful and we got out at 10.30pm.

When my mom and sister came to visit for 3 weeks, we ate out EVERY day, trying out new restaurants from yelp reviews. My sister fell in love and wanted to come back. That was something.
author: Inez J.

description:
Overall, the food was okay.
Not good for eating family style unless you're hella rich. 
Too expensive to go with a group. 
Very small portions (wah wah wah...) . 
Nice atmosphere suitable to impress a date. Most appetizers come with vermicelli (nuts and scallion garnish), fresh herbs, and cucumber. Very nice service. 
They speak Vietnamese and English.
Imperial rolls and spring rolls were standard. Not outstanding. Eensie weensie portions.
Bo la lot was very yummy if you're into grape leaves wrapped beef. Mmmm
Chao Tom was chewy and didnt come with banh hoi. Not worth it.
Rice claypot was DERICIOUS. Shrimpies, chinese sausage, mushrooms, bamboo, ginger, scallion, saucy goodness. Didn't get enough. 6 people gets about 2-3 bites max.
Garlic noodles were VERY garlicky made with spaghetti pasta and butter sauce.
Bo luc lac was pretty yummy. Nothing spectacular. 

Mmmhmmm...C'est La Vie!
author: Thu T.

description:
I have been coming here for years.  The family that runs this place is great.  The food is simple, fresh and tasty.  My personal favorite is the flaming beef with prawns appetizer.  It is so delicious and it is always fun to see your food go up in flames next to your table.   Their salt and pepper squid ...yum.  Their soups are amazing.  Basically it is all great. 

Man! Now I am hungry.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Wow... I can't believe I'm going to do this but I will!

My sis is a regular takeout from this place and she suggested to get food here this past weekend ... it was raining and cold. Fine.

I called and ordered the following for the family:
- Vietnamese BBQ Pork =  eck! I thought it would taste like a regular grilled beef deal but to no avail! I also thought it'd taste like Goldilocks, but I was wrong again. Without the accompanying sauce, this dish had a weird taste to it! You've been warned!

- Five Special Roast Chicken = the token decent dish from this place. Unfortunately, my nephew was hungry so he didn't want to share much. 

- Clay Pot Special = parents compared it to Le Chavel in Oakland... of course that's an automatic failed. They said it didn't have much but rice but even the rice tasted like it was on top not cooked in the clay pot itself. 

- Chicken Noodle Soup = ordered this for the bro.in.law and we got fooled! They gave him all veggies NO chicken! WTH?

Also, when the nephew came in to pick up the food, they added an extra $5 from the total that I was given at the phone, just cause he was a kid! Good thing the nephew asked him twice regarding the cost... and then the guy finally said the right amount.

NEVER again! Crappy and overpriced food... even on take out... I can't imagine how it is inside! 

Last... don't give them the benefit that what you ordered will be in the bag, I learned that lesson the hard way!
author: Cath M.

description:
La Vie has by far the BEST Pho that I have EVER tasted - the flavor of just the broth alone is to die for. My friend and I shared an appetizer which was so delicious that I could have ordered maybe two more to go and enjoyed it as a snack later. Up to this day, I still crave the Pho and Appetizer. 

Sadly, that is literally the only good thing that I can say about this restaurant. And while I believe most people aim to create dishes as incredible and savory as the ones I had at La Vie, I also strongly believe that the service makes a huge impact in someone's overall experience.  Especially when it comes to dining in at a restaurant that you intend to stay at for longer than 15-20 minutes. 

When my friend and I got to the restaurant, we were seated immediately because there was only one other group. The waitress took our order within the first 5 mins of us being seated because we pretty much knew what we wanted right away. I ordered a Vietnamese coffee to enjoy with my meal because I wanted to have enough energy to drive back home after (just came from a relaxing spa appt. and had an hour drive back home ahead of me). Our food came relatively quickly, then after that - I'm 100% sure our waitress either forgot about us, or just didn't care. She didn't bother to check in on us any time after bringing out our food. She had no problem entertaining another table for a good half hour.  We waited our entire meal for the coffee until we were finally over it, then waited another 15-20 mins for her so we can get the bill.  My friend had to go up to her and interrupt her conversation with the table to ask for our bill and told her to cancel the coffee that she never got for us.  Her response was, "Oh, I had it in the back." My friend was not impressed and said, "We ordered it over an hour ago- we didn't order it to wait until our meal was done, which we also finished about 30 minutes ago and you haven't check on us for about 50 minutes now." It was ridiculous. She definitely did not get a tip from us. It was really unfortunate because the food was so delicious and that is the ONLY reason I give this place two stars.

I would probably not go here to dine in again.  I'd more than likely only order to go because the food is that good but the service is terrible.
author: Pamela G.

description:
I've walked past this restaurant many times without ever really noticing it.  The outside decor of the place is pretty plain.  So while taking a slow walk on Geary while hiking up to the Legion of Honor one day I actually did notice there is a restaurant here.  It was pretty empty around 1:30 in the afternoon and I recall there were maybe two other customers at the time.

The gentleman who waited on tables that afternoon was constantly smiling and very gracious with his service constantly checking to see if everything was okay.  He brought me a pot of tea and he told me he had just prepared it as I walked in the the door.  I didn't like the tea however, but his preparation of it had nothing to do with that.  I simply didn't like the strong, flowery fragrance in the tea; I thought it was far too perfumy.  It tasted nothing like normal hot tea.

I took a moment to study the large menu.  I ordered the Imperial Roll and the Seafood Crispy Egg Nest (both pictured).  The wait for my food was not too bad.  The Imperial Rolls arrived first nicely plated but showcasing a mound of greens (leaf lettuce, basil & fresh mint) instead of the five measly egg rolls set off to one side.  The rolls were very tasty with finely minced ingredients in the filling.  I noticed the ground pork, some shrimp bits, mushrooms and carrots.  The clear dipping sauce decorated by strings of carrot and bits of red chiles was quite good.  A small portion of pickled carrot shreds and a small mound of rice vermicelli dusted with crushed peanuts also went onto the plating.  I did end up eating most of the greens and thought it went well with the two additional sides.

The Seafood Crispy Egg Nest took a bit more preparation time, but it arrived piping hot and beautifully plattered.  On a deep fried egg noodle "nest" were lots of tender calamari, some medium sized shrimp, whole scallops and a vegetable medley of mushrooms, broccoli, celery, carrots, zucchini and onion in a very light sauce.  It was an excellent dish, and I waddled out of that restaurant enormously stuffed.

The restaurant has a very clean interior, but some of the menu items are quite pricey.  With the exception of the aromatic tea I liked it and I think it deserves 4.5 stars.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Honestly the best sandwich/spring rolls I've had since I went to veitnam...service was acceptional as well as wait time. Plenty of space to relax and enjoy the outdoor surroundings. Even at the busiest time Jerimie would keep us informed about our order. Thank you sooooooo oooohhhh much. Keep up the good work!
author: James H.

description:
Cute little unpretentious cafe that is very clean and you'll be greeted right away with an informal neighborhood "Hello" right as you step in.
The service remained charming and friendly throughout our dinner. The food was superb! Well prepared, deliciously seasoned and nicely presented. My friend and I shared a green bean appetizer made with little cured radishes and a soy-mushroom sauce that was AMAZING and I highly recommend you try this. Then we had lemongrass grilled pork chop, 5 spice roasted chicken and steamed rice all delicious! For all this plus a soda and a Vietnamese coffee was about forty bucks! 
I have been an executive chef in San Francisco for over 11 years. I do not praise easily! go have a meal at La Vie!
author: Michael B.

description:
No complaints.  
Good quality food.  
Fast service.  Welcoming Service.  

I've ordered takeout from here and have eaten-in.  The food is equally good both ways of dining, but there is just something nice about sitting in the restaurant to enjoy it hot from the kitchen. There isn't anything fancy about the place, it is simply very welcoming and cozy.  Love the music (yay I don't have to compete with TVs on the walls).  Really the mood asks you to stay, enjoy your food and enjoy the company you're with (even if you're solo).

This is my go-to for Vietnamese dining.
author: Rachel G.

description: Awesome and sweetest customer service, decadent French Vietnamese cuisine. Great for family dinners.
author: Alissa L.

description:
Finally. A decent Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco! As a Vietnamese person from San Jose, "Vietnamese food" in San Francisco has been extremely disappointing. 

I had the Bun Thit Nuong and it was actually pretty good. I was pleasantly surprised that the nuoc mam (fish sauce) actually tasted how it is supposed to. That simple sauce is hard to get right, and they got it right. 

Pricing is a bit on the higher side comparing to prices back in San Jo, BUT, for the first time getting decent Vietnamese food in the past year, I'll take it for now. 

I'll definitely have to come back to try their other dishes.
author: Anastasia D.

description: They even made the Spicy Mango Shrimp/Chicken without the shrimp! No problem! These guys are great!
author: Donna D.

description:
BEST. CRAB. EVERRR.

I'll say it again. Probably the best crab I've EVER had so far. It didn't come cheap though-- about $50 for one crab. However, it was a very big crab, definitely fresh, flavorful and very tasty.

AMBIANCE:
Came in around 3-4pm. It was a bit dark inside, but other than that very clean and well maintained.

FOOD:
Garlic Butter Crab: DELICIOUS. Words can't describe it. I love how they give you a tiny fork so you can really dig in and get the meat out of each crevice. No crab went to waste.
Garlic Noodles: Didn't care for it much and did not live up to my expectations, but I was so into the crab that I didn't care. Still think Perilla has the best garlic noodles.
Starter #15: I can't remember the name, but it was an interesting appetizer of raw beef, shrimp, and veggies that came in a ceramic bowl which they lit on fire table side. They cook all the ingredients down and bring a plate of more veggies (carrots, lettuce, cucumbers, fish sauce) and some rice roll papers. It's like make your own fresh spring rolls. Delicious!

SERVICE:
It was pretty quiet when I went, so service was very attentive and friendly. 

The total bill came out to around  ~$95 with tip and tax for 3 dishes.

Would I come again? FOR THE CRAB @__@
author: Jenna H.

description: Food is whatever, small portions. Only one person running the whole place can't be good. All I can say is pay attention to your order and receipt. Twice now I have been over charged on my order.. A little shaddy if you ask me. This place is willing to take advantage of people every chance it gets..
author: Ricky W.

description:
This place is truly a hidden gem. Went here on a date and setting was calm, quiet and intimate. Server was on point, timely and pretty much all we can ask for without overdoing it. The food was legit. We kinda overdid it on the order but the Pho was good, the Roasted Crab with garlic noodles was amazing but mainly the Flaming Beef was something different and taste amazing. Pair that with a glass of wine and you have a winning dinner. We ate nearly everything. Would most definitely come back again.

Only reason why I wouldnt rate it a 5 star is because it wasn't an outer-worldly experience or setting. Just another really good restaurant.
author: AQ N.

description: I start out with their tea and fresh spring rolls followed by their chicken Pho. But whether it's their lunch and dinner specials of the day, be prepared for authentic Vietnamese eats with a welcoming staff and great service. I ate here once and Suze Orman was across the way. Trust me, it's worth every penny.
author: J C.

description:
Best Vietnamese Restaurant in San Francisco! 
Service is attentive, knowledgable, friendly, and punctual. 
Family owned and operated. This shows, they really care about The mother is the chef and she does not dissapoint. 
Specials are always good. I haven't had a dish here I didn't like. 
3 or 4 different kinds of crab. Her garlic noodles blow " the other place" out of the water. 
Try the Pork in anything. 
The Pho... Just do it! 
Clean and all produce is fresh, fresh, fresh.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
This place is by far my favorite place to go to to eat pho! There is something about the pho broth that makes this restaurant stand out from the rest of the Vietnamese restaurants. 
I'd also recommend getting the La Vie Combo, Flaming Beef, the crab with the garlic noodles, their vegetable dishes, pork chop & their pannacotta.
The restaurant is very clean and well-kept. There's usually not that many people there during the day and weekday evenings. 
Yes the food on the menu is over-priced compared to other Vietnamese restaurants, but I think it's worth it.
Oh the reason for the minus 1 star is that service is slow sometimes...
author: Selina T.

description:
So so. For months (heck, I mean, years) I've been walking by this place but I never went inside. They always have a sign outside saying "Vietnamese sandwiches" and yesterday afternoon I was craving Vietnamese Sandwiches like no other (and heck I was hungry too!). 

When I decided to finally give this spot a try, instead of my regular Vietnamese spot by my house, I went inside and asked for Vietnamese sandwiches and they didn't have any apparently. Now, I was hungry, so I decided to just order anything to feed my body. 

I order the spring rolls and upon recommendation of the server/hostess I order a vegetarian curry. The Spring Rolls were dry & the curry just didn't taste that good in general. Veggies were off and there was hardly any curry sauce. 

It satisfied my hunger, but it didn't satisfy my cravings. Today I will go back to my regular Vietnamese spot on Clement street and order my Vietnamese sandwich, nom nom. 

Probably won't go back here, plenty of good Vietnamese spots in the area.
author: Helen D.

description:
TAMARIND CRAB is all I have to say.
