Their tamaraind flavored crab is better than all the other crab places in SF (like PPQ & Thang Long) in my opinion.

Garlic noodles is soggy tho. Could be improved. But when you smother the noodles with the excess tamarind sauce, it's actually pretty bomb.
author: Annie H.

description:
To summarize: horrible service, but good food.

We pre-ordered for a large group the night before, but still did not get served for over an hour.  When we were seated, the waiter / owner(?) told us the crabs were ready and he was just waiting for us.  Then nothing came out of the kitchen for 1 hour.  

Maybe this place is better for a group of just a few people-- we had 16, which was too much for them to handle apparently.
author: Vic S.

description:
I agree with Vic S. The food is good, however the service/mgt ... there is a lot of improvement to do here.

Here a pure example : we ordered by phone some food (For 4 people). The person on the phone repeats after me exactly what I ordered, so no mistake is made.
He says to come in 30 minutes, which we did, once we arrived, food is not ready... fine shit happens, we wait, around 20 minutes more... 

finally we got the food, go back home (4 blocks away) and once we arrived, one of the dish is not what we ordered. My gf is pissed (normal!) she wrote a review here on yelp saying she did not get what she ordered, got a response from the restaurant here, and reply and then review is removed from yelp. What kind of business does that ?! Yelp why doing it too ?
author: Renaud P.

description:
While in the Richmond District, and not in the mood for Chinese or Japanese, I found La Vie!  

At first I was a bit skeptical about what I was getting myself into as their was white table cloth and tea candles set throughout the tables. Furthermore, there was only one other table during prime dinner time.    But I wasn't about to look for another restaurant in the cold, and much of Richmond has been so mediocre for me lately too.   So I gave La Vie a chance. I'm glad I did.   

The ambiance is simple, just tables and white walls decorated with three Asian instruments on the side walls.  There was also a very elegant Christmas Tree as well--very pretty.  

Our server was a very cheerful and friendly younger Asian gal. She was a great server to have as she offered great recommendations for entrees and for our dessert as well.  I will get to dessert much later.  

For appetizers, we started off with the Salt and Pepper Fried Calamari.  It came nicely plated with a side of cabbage as well.  The batter for the calamari was a bit thin and minimal, and I would've preferred it to be a bit crunchier.  But the flavor was awesome as it had nice bits of crushed garlic, jalapenos, bell peppers and parsley.  While it was full of flavor, my only complaint about the dish is that there was so much garnish in terms of the jalapenos, parsley, etc, that it made the dish appear larger than it actually was. In turn, there weren't as many calamari pieces given as I would've liked.  http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/OkJ1iRWFNMQepXDC6JyUAg/l

For entrees, we ordered three dishes.

* La Vie Chicken - http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/1q0cNeZRtyrLDG27fP0iTA/l  Full of flavor, nice and saucy. Dish consisted of coconut milk with curry peanuts basil, cucumber and slices of crispy romaine lettuce.  Everything was equally dispersed and blended very well together; there were also dry chili pieces for that extra kick. 

* Green Beans with Radish- http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/JhnlZhp30yEGmQeMKdD9Hg/l  This dish was at the recommendation of our server.  Awesome dish.  Juicy beans lightly cooked in oil, with chopped garlic pieces, and bits of sweet radish as well. I popped these things in my mouth like candy!  

* Garlic Noodles - http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/kjjVV8mo8eYsQGG9H393UQ/l  Unfortunately, not all of the entrees were doing so great.  Garlic noodles were a real disappointment.  My first complaint is that the noodles used are regular spaghetti noodles.  What a bummer! I was expecting them to be some sort of Asian noodles with a bit of a bite to them.   But not the case. Further more, there was not enough garlic flavor, and in stead, there was some Parmesan cheese drizzled on top. This made the noodles a bit dry.  Too bad, because I love love love garlic noodles, but I did not love these.  

Dessert!  

* Vanilla Panna Cotta with Mango Puree - http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/y1fv31zLBIi8WXXZl1zdHA/l.  *Licks lip*  Y u m m y !  Our server also made this recommendation to us as well, I'm glad I took it because there were other dessert items that caught my eye...but next time.  As for the Panna Cotta, it was nice and creamy, and had an awesome subtle vanilla taste, not overpoweringly sweet; the mango puree and chopped mango pieces complimented the vanilla very well.  

Our nice server also sent over a complimentary order of a Tiramisu, however, rather than being espresso flavored, it was filled with some sort of Asian fruit, and coconut bits.  I'm unable to describe this dish very well as it wasn't on the menu, and given to us as a comp, but a fruity Tiramisu with coconuts sold me!   

To sum up, I enjoyed dinner here very much!  The prices are much HIGHER than I normally would've paid for Vietnamese.   I would have like to see a little bit more on the plate in general.  But for the most part all of the dishes made up for the size, in terms of flavor-- With the exception of the Garlic Noodles.  

Total Bill came out to around $55.00. 

I will return.
author: Cass J.

description:
We are a big fan of Vietnamese food from the bun rice noodle salads to pho.  We've tried a lot of places all over the city, and this is the best so far.  

What we like:
- shrimp & pork rolls
- rice noodle salad (bun)
- garlic noodles 

I'm also a fan of their chicken pho:  I like the silver noodles, the broth, and the veggies.  However, for some reason the chicken is always dry.  Also, sometimes the bean sprouts are beginning to brown.  

None the less, we are a fan of this place and the people, so will continue to come back!
author: Jade F.

description:
This is my go to for pho! It may not be as traditional as a lot of other places, but the quality is great :) It's a great place to take friends who are visiting to you from out of town or for a quiet and romantic dinner. Really great for dates!! I have had the beef pho, beef pho duo, and the beef luk lac (i think that's how it's spelled? I know it's pronounced "look luck") I was never once disappointed by the food and the service is wonderful! 

As for why I didn't rate it 5 stars? It takes awhile to get the food as there are not too many people working at any one time. The service is wonderful, but I think maybe there should be more people to help out. The poor waitress that's there seems to be the only one!

Now some tips: You don't have to do a reservation unless if it is a little later in the evening on a Friday or Saturday, then it fills up. If you want to bring your kids, that's fine, just be ready to constantly tell them to be patient. I have seen a lot of families bring kids and the kids always seem to get antsy while waiting for the food, which tends to stress the parents. Parking is difficult to find!! It is MUCH easier to take the bus or walk. If a car is your option, be sure show up early so you can find a spot. Final tip. Patience, patience, patience. I promise you it is worth the wait!
author: Krystina C.

description:
My inner skeptic doesn't allow me to give a place five stars the first time I visit, but we argued about it quite a bit. This place really is pretty fantastic. 

I'll preface by admitting that my knowledge of Vietnamese cuisine is fairly limited. My employer and I ordered two items for lunch that I'd never had: the 5-spice chicken, (which I've seen on several Vietnamese menus) and the coconut curry noodles with prawns.

We indicated that we were on a tight schedule and asked if the items we ordered were appropriate for a quick getaway. The server ensured us that she would make sure we would get out in time for our meeting. I was pleased that they were accommodating and that although the food came out quickly, it was still made well. They brought out the bill at the same time as our food to help speed up the process.

The combination of flavors was delicious! The cuts of chicken were pretty lean and you could tell by the texture that they used fresh prawns versus frozen.

I would love to come back here for dinner and help them earn their five-star review. The ambience is simple, cozy, and classy, but not overly-elegant.
author: Suganthi J.

description:
I found this place through yelp last weekend when the fiancee and I decided to take a lunch break from our walk through GG park. 

When we sat down, at first I thought maybe I had made a mistake. Yelp doesn't really do a good job of helping you find a good lunch place. The "$" places tend to be just coffee and tea and the "$$" category can often send you to a place like La Vie, where the white tablecloths and heavy silverware signaled I'd probably be spending a bit more than I planned. We ordered Thai Iced Tea and (a) I didn't like it because it was not as strong as usual and (b) it was $4. So I sent it back even though it felt really awkward because it would have felt even worse to pay $4 for a glass of tea I didn't even like. 

I was thinking: maybe we should leave, all I really need is a sandwich. Then the food arrived and I changed my mind absolutely.

I'd expected to like the fried calamari, because, hey, deep fried calamari, how can you go wrong, right? But this was amazingly awesome calamari. First of all, it was fried perfectly. Second of all, it had a tasty salt-and-pepper batter which was both lighter and much tastier than whatever is usually on there. And then thirdly, it was tossed with a bunch of other tasty stuff which (two days later) I no longer remember but included veggies and fried garlic. Also, miraculously, these tossings were dry enough that the calamari did not get soggy as usually happens when you mix in deep fried stuff.

The "Lotus Root Salad" had not looked promising on the menu. It was my fiancee's idea (we were splitting dishes) and she is very enthusiastic about lotus root, a vegetable I consider to be dubious. I don't *hate* it, like I do potatoes, but it's not exactly high up there on the list of choices.  I didn't see any point in trying to make a salad out of it. 

And they don't, really. What they do is deep-fry a few slices of lotus (which is fabulous) and use them to decorate the sides of the salad. The salad itself is served in a tasty bowl of fried eggroll wrapper and is your basic tasty Vietnamese salad with lettuce and peppers and thin slices of pork, among other things. I really wish they had a menu online somewhere, because I know I'm not doing it justice.

Both the salad and the calamari were extremely good, several levels above your standard Vietnamese fare. Of course, it's a nicer type of restaurant, so you would be expecting better food anyway. But even considering this, it is outstanding. I didn't give it 5 stars because I reserve that for the truly exceptional places but somebody else might have. 

I think the bill was $28 for a salad, an appetizer, one glass of iced tea, and tax. At lunch. So it's kind of a lot. But by that point we no longer minded because the food was so good.

Their menu needs to be re-written. It neither accurately describes nor gets you excited about what you're about to eat. There's no website or (as far as I can tell) any online menu. This is bad because now I can't remember what I ate or budget for our return for dinner (which, upon leaving we had wanted to do). We can't just go and look in the window bc we don't live there.

I wouldn't recommend it for lunch though, unless you're looking for a fancy lunch. They're more of a dinner place.
author: Amy T.

description:
It's the second time my friends and I have been to La Vie for a birthday celebration.  The first time, we did family style to try more dishes, the second time, family styled it again.


We had a rather large party so we divided the table in half. Folks on my half, the cool half, agreed on having garlic noodles, the spicy coconut crab, curry eggplant, the flaming beef, lemongrass chicken as well as the bo luc lac.


The flaming beef came out first and ou it was on FIYA - literally.  They had a bowl of beef, seasoned and on top of a dish which they set on fire for it to cook.  It was such a show since the place was dim - had everyone and they mama lookin' our way.   After the flames set, the waitress brought the bowl over and you actually get to roll your own spring rolls with the beef! So fun, so yum.


The only downside was that after that first flaming beef dish, it took FOREVER for the next entrees to come and we were HUNGRY. It was about a 30 minute intermission before the next rounds of food appeared. [Good thing we had a big party so all the chitty chatty helped kill some time]  The lemongrass chicken was pretty good since it was loaded with peppers/onions, the whole stinky breath works, but the curry eggplant - howlllaaa. Def. something you need to try. Garlic noodles, also deelish.  Bo luc lac was yummy with its own dipping sauce, don't forget about the dipping sauce!  


The last and most awaited dish finally came, the crab!  They remove the top shell so no guts for all you gut lovers.  We all tried to stay classy but man, there is no clean way to eat a crab so we just dove right in, snapping and cracking away.  Whatever they had UNDER the shell -- bits of noodles and oodles of sauce --  ya'll need to get up in that cause it was bombtastic and tasted a little like heaven. Mm mm mm.   They hooked it up with some coconut ice cream/fried banana/brownie dessert for the birthday folks ... as well as one for the cool half.
author: Annie C.

description: I love this place! I highly recommend them. They only use the freshest ingredients and always have amazing customer service. They really care about their food and it tells!  I eat here quite often! Everything I've had here is amazing, I especially like the five spice chicken, Vietnamese crêpe, Shaking beef, Imperial Rolls and their desserts. I've never had anything bad here! They also offer a fantastic wine list my favorite wine is there squeezebox red.
author: Jay M.

description: only based on Pho. Very good broth but everything else was lacking in serving size. There was no dac biet which left the meat to some well done flank or such and meat ball and the meat ball was less impressive then what you can find at the asian market. Let me say again the broth was amazing but the price and serving size and meat selection left me wanting more.
author: Matt B.

description: I've been meaning to write this review. So here it goes. I came here a couple of weeks ago for my best friends birthday.  I don't know why I haven't been to this place ever. I lived in the Richmond district all my life. This place is a definite local gem. Must haves are the garlic noodles and crab. We tried the la vie style which is roasted and garlic steamed butter style. Both cooked to perfection.  Also ordered the flaming beef which was presented beautifully. Everything we ordered was amazing. All ingredients here are fresh and you can tell the quality is excellent. I will come back for sure la vie to try your eclectic menu. Great vietnamese spot, not like your average whole in the wall spot.Support your local businesses!
author: Nana P.

description:
Too much grease and MSG !

I stopped coming to the restaurant because the cook uses too much grease and MSG in the dishes - soups and stir fries.  After each meal, I got heartburn from the grease and flushing, headache and excessive thirst from the MSG.  I wish they can make my dishes without all the grease and MSG.  I live close by and would enjoy their food without the side effects of excessive grease and MSG.
author: G D.

description:
Crab? Did somebody say crab??? A few years ago, some friends introduced me to the Vietnamese Roasted Crab experience. After hearing about the famed Thanh Long (offshoots - Crustacean - SF, Beverly Hills, & Las Vegas), friends raved about the experience. Since we can't jump into the Back to the Future experience and taste what it really was twenty or thirty years ago, I need to talk about the now. 

Vietnamese Roasted Crab = Perfectly pan roasted crab (timing is critical in ensuring that it is not overcooked - meat sticks to the shell - and flavorful. The crab is quartered (duh, I think one crab serves four) and the gao (aka "crab butter", brains, that icky orange stuff that sticks to the main shell) is stir fried in an egg, garlic, ground pork (I believe), and some other mystery seasonings into a scrambled mix. This dish comes with a complimentary plate of garlic noodles (think lightly buttered spaghetti noodles mixed with browned garlic and topped with cilantro) - we usually double up on the noodles. The crab is still warm (not, "I can't hold this without burning my hand", hot) while the stir fry mix sits centered on the plate. You mix the garlic noodles with the gao mix and just say "mmmmmm..." aka nom nom nom. They later give diners individual lemon tea dipping bowls and paper napkins because they know their crab is finger licking good. Depending on the season, the crab prices can range from $40.00 to $50.00, so this is not for the faint hearted. 

Appetizers 

La Vie Combo - Three skewers of grilled shrimp (1 skewer - 3 pieces), bbq pork (2 skewers), and four small imperial rolls with romaine lettuce, mint leaves, pickled carrots, cucumber wedges, and fish sauce. It comes with six individual rice crepes to wrap the above in whatever combination you desire. 

Crab meat & Corn Soup - Shredded crab meat and corn in a clear chicken broth seasoned with pepper and garnished with green onions. 

Main Courses 

Citrus Scallops - Stir fried scallops with zucchini, carrots, oranges, and pineapple wedges, garnished with fried rice noodles and cilantro; doesn't compare to the seared scallops from yesterday.. okay though. 

Eggplant in garlic sauce - Stir fried eggplant slices with red bell peppers and onions. 

Clay Pot Special Rice - Seasoned rice with Chinese sausage (lop cheung), chicken meat, shrimp, bamboo shoots, onions, and light ginger flavoring; again, doesn't compare to the Chinese clay pot rice dishes where the rice is perfectly browned as it sticks to the seasoned pot. 

The total bill for four people (including three glasses of Thai Iced Tea) came to $147.00 before tip. We were one of the first to arrive at around 6 pm, as parking can be difficult here. There is a metered lot (in effect until 10 pm) about one block away in case you are unlucky. The dining room was about half full when we left. The highlight is obviously the crab. I've heard numerous complaints about the above mentioned SF crab places, but I can't personally say as I've never dined there. One of the owners told me the difference is that La Vie uses larger crabs in the three to four pound range when available. This is a major difference since no one wants to just suck on a bunch of shells. Whenever my dad is in a down mood or craving for something, the first two words from his mouth is usually, "La Vie". Gee dad, I didn't know you spoke French.
author: Mike C.

description: Just thinking about the dishes at La Vie makes me hungry. Everything is prepared with love, care and freshness. The CRAB - oh my gosh. I can't name all of the dishes that I have enjoyed with friends and family - but this is the place to go.
author: Theresa C.

description:
I'm really not sure why La Vie ONLY has 3 and a half stars, but I have never had a problem with the service and the food is excellent! 

I used to live in the neighborhood and would go a little more often with my family, but ever since we moved to the other side of GGP, we haven't frequented La Vie quite as often. 

Usually, we get the flaming beef - it's tasty and entertaining to watch! :) Last time we came here we got the clay pot and I know we got a dessert as well...

All in all, I have always been really pleased with the food and the waitress we had was the niece of the owners?? It's nice to see that family owned restaurants like this still exist! 

We're actually going here tonight again to celebrate my parent's anniversary, so I'll definitely update this review. 

I guess, if you have a problem with your bill, etc...I would just address it and clarify it with the staff before leaving the restaurant....
author: Alison N.

description:
I've been coming to this place for several years and have brought friends and family to eat here.  Hands down, their roasted crab with garlic noodles is the best in town.  Yes it's pricier, but you get what you pay for.  I'm not a big crab eater in restaurants, but La Vie's crab is worth getting your hands dirty.  It's absolutely sumptuous and incredibly flavorful.  Our friends have become repeat customers as well.  

It's really worth it to give La Vie a try.  You won't regret it.
author: Shirley L.

description: This place is good, authentic Vietnamese food. Inexpensive as well. We stopped here after Hardly Strictly in the park and wanted something for a vegan and 2 omnivores. This was a great compromise. We had the veg spring rolls, which were delicious, as was the sauce that goes with it. I had the crispy egg nest noodles, which I loved. Fresh herbs and veggies. Good noodles. Can't beat it! Note: check out the sign on the bathroom door. You have to see it to believe it. I'll leave it at that :)
author: Susan V.

description: This is a favorite restaurant for me and many friends. Family owned and run, really great, authentic food, great service (the waitress always remembers me and my partner). This place has the best phó I've ever had, both beef and chicken. Their special crab is off the charts delicious!
author: Cary R.

description:
My friend & I were in the neighborhood last weekend searching for a place to have lunch. Enter the oh-so-useful Yelp app! We randomly picked La Vie (they do have 4 stars after all). 

We were in a bit of a time crunch cuz we were only able to scrounge up $2 in change for our meter & that only gave us an hour. We told our happy waiter this & boy, did he expedite our food! Much appreciated! 

I ordered the spicy lemongrass chicken over noodles. Yum! I love anything with lemongrass and this dish had just the right amount of spice. There were also tons of string beans in this dish. Another fave of mine! I couldn't finish it all but my friend gladly swooped in to clean the plate. 

It is a bit pricier than most Vietnamese restaurants but the food was well worth it. I'd love to come back sometime & try one of their crab dishes!
author: Erin S.

description: Nice decor. Mainly one of those Asian restaurants that are filled with anything but Asians. Nonetheless, the food was good. We ordered a bunch of dishes because being the hungry hippo that I am, I have to have a variety of plates. We got the Banh xeo (Vietnamese crepe), spring rolls, garlic noodles, and this fried meatball dish.  The sauces for each dish definitely stood out. The banh xeo could've used more lettuce though. Unfortunately we didn't try the flaming beef that everyone else on yelp raved about. Maybe next time!
author: Lily Z.

description: Great salt and pepper, and roasted crab plus come with awesome garlic noodles. Chicken lettuce wraps are a good app.
author: Jesse W.

description: Randomly choose this restaurant because we were in the area without plans.   Was not disappointed.  Food was closest to authentic that I've had.  Flavorable without to much heat.   Will go back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Michael B.

description: This restaurant has delicious, subtle food. I love the Seafood Crispy Egg Nest. The sauce is really tasty and the noodles start crisp and end soft and saucy. And they have the best BBQ pork that I've ever tried. The Vietnamese Salad is also excellent.
author: Sharon G.

description: Great food and service. Love their fresh crab and Buc La Loi.
author: Matthew B.

description:
Tonight was the night. The night I paid more than $40 for a single dish at a Vietnamese restaurant. I didn't eat all day, priming my stomach for a challenge. And I got it:  La Vie Roasted Crab with Garlic Noodles. It was amazing - savory, garlicy, crab-tastic. If you like crab, you owe it to yourself to plunk down the money to enjoy this dish!

While I enjoyed my crab, he was less impressed with his meal. He started with the Lemongrass Chicken, which was tasty but not exactly packed with meat. The dish's composition was about 2/3 veggies and 1/3 chicken. To augment the meal, he got the Vietnamese BBQ Pork, served on skewers with ngoc mam. This was a tasty addition, though almost required due to the lack of protein in the other dish.

We've been before, and we'll be back again. As long as you're smart about what you order, you'll leave full and happy!
author: Karen C.

description:
Do not go here to eat! Having worked in restaurants and being a profoundly grateful person, I NEVER walk out of a restaurant. I just walked out of this one. We
waited 10 mins and had to get the waiters attention--to have to ask for water. Then, we asked if we could have the Thai ice tea made with coconut milk instead of half-and-half.The waiter told us no, but luckily the woman working there overhead the question and answered yes. The tea, however, tasted as if it had still been made with half-and-half. so, we waited another 10 minutes and no one came to take order. I attempted to get the woman's attention, but she was busy taking 'to-go' orders on the phone, and cleaning off a table. The waiter made eye contact with me, our menus were on the table closed, and walked the opposite direction! I got up and walked out and as my boyfriend was doing the same, the waiter started hassling him to pay for the two teas! The woman apologized for the slow and horrible service (and still took his money!). The restaurant was pretty full; however, not overwhelmingly so. We walked across the street to a dim-sum restaurant and had a great meal with excellent service.
-------------------------------------------------
and just to clarify, for all of you in Yelpland, based on the response I received from the woman I presume is the owner: yes, I have had fresh coconut milk extensively, both with and without Thai ice tea. Maybe it was made with coconut milk as we had requested, and not half-and-half ; however, it tasted unlike any Thai ice tea made with coconut milk we have ever had (and not in a good way!)--which is why we did not drink them, other than a few sips through our straws to taste. Upon further talking with my boyfriend, he did inform me that she did not apologize for the ridiculously long wait (what I would consider ignoring, multiple times). As far as her comment that we are thieves- the poor tasting, 90% left in the glasses, Thai ice tea's were paid for with cash before my boyfriend even attempted to walk toward the door to leave. I would really hope that any business owner would work to improve the areas that receive poor ratings and feedback from the customers, unless they are really not interested in keeping customers satisfied, returning, and suggesting to other's to patronage that establishment.
author: Aundrea L.

description:
Perhaps I didn't order the right things, but I thought this place was just OK. Nothing really stood out as any better than other OK Vietnamese places I've been to. I did notice that other tables ordered flaming dishes with table-side service, which looked (and smelled) really cool. But our dishes were just mediocre. 

We started with the Vietnamese crepe, which I always love. This was was good, but not great (the best I've had was at a little hole-in-the-wall place out on Judah or Irving). We also ordered the seafood combo with rice. It had a nice flavor, but there were exactly 3 mussels, 3 shrimp, and 3 small pieces of calamari. We ordered the coconut curry noodles with prawns as well, which I thought was going to be sweet but ended up being so spicy I couldn't eat it. 

The service was very nice, if a little slow. Perhaps I'll try it again and order some flaming dishes, but with all of the other options in the neighborhood and in the city I don't see why I'd go back.
author: Amy B.

description:
I am a regular to Pho Garden on Clement.  Yet, of late they are now closed on Tuesdays which disrupts my entire Pho routine.  Turns out this is what led me to La Vie and change is apparently just what I needed. 

While the prices are a bit more expensive than my usual Pho haunts, you get what you pay for.  

The Pho is visibly better quality at La Vie, their starters are always delicious and their service is friendly and enjoyable.  

The salty plum tonic and passion fruit ice tea are refreshing and go great with the hot steamy Pho varietals.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: I'm a regular customer there .  I like the inviroment , the service , the food .....  I recommend it .  I brought some friends there and they loved it too .  Thanks to La Vie
author: Lien L.

description: For $8, this is some pretty good pho. Bonus points for not looking like a hole in the wall. For those on a hot date who has never tried pho, this is a good place to start!
author: Andy A.

description:
Sandwiched between a peaceful coi fish tank in the front and two tanks full of fresh and feisty dungeness crabs in the back is a cozy and tastefully decorated dining area. I appreciate the small touches, like uniform fresh rose buds on every table.

The food is pretty darn tasty and authentic. We enjoyed the garlic noodles, chicken curry, and vegetarian hot and sour soup. 

The garlic noodles are not the green ones you'd find at Osha. They're simply spaghetti noodles flavored with chunks of garlic, fresh cilantro and sprinkled with parmesan. Not what I'd typically order at a vietnamese restaurant but I was feeling a bit ill and wanted something easy on the digestive system. In case you're wondering, I'm happy to report it stayed down- and was really tasty.

The vegetarian hot and sour soup is not only hearty, with good chunks of veggies and potatos (is a potato a vegetable?), but will also clean out your sinuses. My friend couldn't stop blowing her nose. 

The pot of tea seemed to be bottomless- totally worth the $4.50 for at least 3-4 cups per 3 people.  

Tab ran the three of us $42 total. I wouldn't make a special trip to eat here, but highly recommend chowing down if you're in the area!
author: Kim K.

description: Top quality no fail Viet food.. Only down side is the high prices.. I would be here weekly, though with 2 ppl at 80.-100 at dinner, the beau and I reserve this special place for special occasions only. Perhaps, they will open up a lower priced, less fancy option? I would be there  !!!!!
author: Jenise C.

description: Very slow service. The food is not authentic vietnamese. The catfish in the canh chua (hot & sour soup) was dry and chewy. They served the soup like a chinese restaurant. The coconut shrimp dish was small and pricey. For the price we paid, the place wasn't worth it.
author: Mike N.

description: Great Vietnamese /french style food, I highly recommend the flaming beef dish. also their PHO is very interesting in taste might be a northern style, It's different from most Pho places I've tried. my friend rave so much about the crabs here, but i have yet to try it...maybe next time.
author: Brandon D.

description:
This is the BEST VIETNAMESE RESTAURANT IN SAN FRANCISCO for my money! Dishes are uncompromisingly fresh,clean and flavorful.........most are made with fresh herbs and vegetables selected daily by the owner/chef and served by her gracious daughter. My favorites are the Vietnamese Crepe, Fresh Spring Rolls and Chicken Pho. La Vie is best known for its Fresh Crab.......it is delicious but messy to eat. If you like eggplant the Garlic Eggplant is the best!
Overall La Vie is as close as you can get to authentic taste of Vietnam here in San Francisco!
author: Art C.

description: We will be there later this month for another birthday dinner. Delish garlic noodles and CRAB.Great service. Cozy ambience and very romantic. Good hole in the wall.
author: C U.

description:
La Vie Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco's Richmond District (on Geary between 22nd and 23rd Ave.) is one of my new favorite restaurants.  La Vie served my and my group of 11 the best Vietnamese cuisine I have ever had the pleasure of eating. The people at the tables on either side of us also agreed that their meals were absolutely fantastic.  

Appetizers: I highly recommend the Imperial roll lettuce wraps that come with delicious accompaniments that include lettuce, mint, carrots and a yummy sauce.

entrees: I recommend the catfish clay pot with steamed rice, which offered a delicious combination of fish, sweetness and spicy flavors, as well as the garlic noodles, lemongrass noodles and vegetable curry (vegan and vegetarian.)  

We were a large "walk-in" group of 11 people on a Sunday night around 8 P.M., and after some shifting and adjusting of tables and chairs, the restaurant managed to accommodate us, and the servers, although busy with other customers, did a great job taking care of our large group.  The main waiter is a friendly and long-term employee, and I understand that the owner of the restaurant is the head chef.

After appetizers, entrees and several bottles of wine, the per person tab with tip included came to $43.  I am definitely returning to La Vie soon, perhaps for a belated birthday party.  I'd love to see a blind tasting of La Vie's cuisine side by side with more expensive places like Slanted Door and Le Colonial.

La Vie was one of my most enjoyable restaurant experiences in a long time.  If you like good food in a relaxed and friendly atmosphere, I think you'll enjoy La Vie Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Tom C.

description: Yay! I'm a fan assuming their crab is as good as it was the few times we visited the restaurant many years ago. I mean serious finger licking ono amazing good crab. Each time we went, this is what we had to order. Well, there were other items since there was a few of us ordering  - but the crab so memorable so that to this day, I try to replicate it home. Why haven't we been back? Well, we try to support our local area! Given that, it takes a lot of inspiration to drive to the city and all. So much to check out in our own digs + hubby likes me to keep on trying to replicate their crab to avoid traffic...
author: Kathi H.

description: This place deserves a 5 star review. I have been coming here for over a decade and every time it is a treat. Try the duck and the crispy rice soup!
author: Greg S.

description: Came here because all the nearby pho places were closed on New Years. Despite the restaurant being only half full, it took a full 20 minutes for someone to take our order. The elderly ladies at the table next to us had to wait even longer. Despite the relatively nice decor, don't be fooled and expect service better than any of the cheapest, dirtiest Vietnamese restaurants you've ever been to. At least at those places you pay less.
author: Joshua L.

description: Prepare to order 2x portion. ordered pho and I got like 5 pieces of beef and a hairball of noodle. They gave me plenty of broth but a fork to taste the soup....I don't think this even warrant a review. Plenty of options down the street.
author: Joseph N.

description:
DO NOT FALL FOR THE CRAB SCAM!

Everything that has a price on the menu is under $20. This is a very modest looking restaurant, where the diner is under the impression that everything on the menu is under $20. DO NOT ORDER ANYTHING LISTED AS MARKET PRICE, INCLUDING THE CRAB. You will be charged an exorbitant fee. The crab is $50 a piece. For a crab. This is clearly a scam. Even lobster at a nice restaurant does not cost $50. And this is not a nice restaurant. We were the only people in the restaurant that night. But apparently, according to the waitress, just the night before the place was packed with people ordering the crab. It is obvious how they make their money. Very sketchy. I wonder who writes all the reviews about the crab on yelp. DO NOT FALL FOR IT.
author: Mitchell M.

description:
OK, it was cold tonight and some pho sounded good for a late dinner.  Hubby yelped this place and it looked like it had a nice ambiance.  Started off with a Thai ice tea and man, it was like drinking sweet heavy cream!!  I didn't even taste the tea of the thai!!  Hmm, minus a point on that.  Then our pho came, I had the beef duo (came with the balls) and hubby had to try the chicken pho.   Ehh, had better pho.  Portions were small, lacked flavor, and was overloaded with red onions!  It was a disappointing meal that was overpriced with small portions.  I gave 2 stars only because the service was quick and friendly and I liked the candlelight setting.
So far, nothing beats Ben Tre in SSF!!
author: Kit L.

description: This places has great Vietnamese food, it's a bit more upscale than your regular pho shop
author: Seaera T.

description: Great soft shell crab. Excellent garlic noodles. Been there twice and both times came away gratified.
author: Michael C.

description:
I have been driving past this restaurant like forever, but for some reason, have never cared to check it out until tonight and that was only cause I was meeting a friend for dinner and she suggested we try  it out and I'm glad I did.

Clean. Modern decor. Intimately lit.

We ordered the following:

Vietnamese Croquettes - came as 4 small balls and was surprisingly good, but super duper crispy....watch out now.
Coconut curry rice noodle with prawns - this was really yummy and was very tasty with a nice kick of spiciness.  Peanut and chili sauce can't go wrong.  Loved it!

Service was on point and our waiter was extremely patient and attentive with us......even though the place was only about 1/4 full.  We sat there for a total of almost 3 hours (I know!!) and they happily let us sit and chat for as long as we wanted.  

I've been noticing their huge red restaurant sign everytime I drive down Geary for the LONGEST time now and am glad I finally got to try it for myself.  I've heard and read mixed reviews, but for the most part, I was really content with the dishes, atmosphere, and service.

I'll probably be coming back.
author: Carmen Y.

description:
My first thought was........do not write a critical review, after all different cultures, different tastes, some people eat dogs, some eat cow brains----hell some even eat each other,  blah, blah, blah. 

But then a pang of conscience struck. Consideration for the plight of those who may follow in my footsteps. So I ponder aloud----who the f@#* boils a chicken, fat and all, and without further preparation, seasoning or warning,  just  throws it in some broth and serves it to an unsuspecting customer? The answer to this query you will find below.

I tried this place because I am a big pho fan, and I read a write-up in the local paper that this place had the best chicken soup version of pho around. Well eckkkk!!!

Hunks of tough chicken, with fat and cartilage still attached, just plopped into the bowl.  And in case you did not get enough grease, the cook plainly deems it unnecessary to skim off the top of the broth the chicken fat that rises----insuring that even if you try to avoid the squishy rubbery fatty chicken in the hope that maybe the broth will be tasty; you are guaranteed  that each spoonful has a minimum 40%  stomach coating (and eventually churning) fat content. I will spare you the details, but let me just say that the subsequent eight hours of chicken-fat-tasting-burps I will not easily forget or forgive La f@#**g Vie.

Not a single one of the four of us at the table, all of whom were excited to taste some tasty chicken soup on a lousy rainy day, could come close to finishing a bowl.

I appreciate that in some places in the world many people do not have enough food, so that when they do get their hands on say, a chicken, they eat damn near everything except maybe the feathers and the beak. However, here in the land of obesity and a thousand Safeways, we no longer NEED to eat globs of fat to insure our survival through the long hard winter. Cook with the fat to add flavor, yes indeed. But actually leaving it or its liquid form en masse in the dish---NO, NO and NOOOOOOOOO.

Two stars, just because I did not try anything else on the menu (nor will I) and because it is the holidays. Mainly the holidays. Otherwise zero.
author: b g.

description:
oh mah gaaaah.

So my friend took me here for lunch on this obscurely rainy San Francisco day and it was the most amazingest lunch I've had ever in the history of my life.

I told her how I was easing into seafood after having been a vegetarian for 16 years, so she suggested this place in the Richmond district that is known for their roasted crab. I wasn't prepared for what was about to enter my mouth, but the mounds of stir fried onion and garlic and yummy yummy goodness straight up made me jizz my pants.

The crab was served with garlic noodles [that weren't too great] and we also ordered hot and sour soup, green beans and a side of rice to balance the flavor bomb that was exploding on our tastebuds. 

If I ever make my way up to SF [which I seldom do], this place would be my definite go to spot to fill up my famished tummy, or even to take a special someone out for some bomb diggity Vietnamese cuisine!

Affordable, great service, great food. 5 deserving stars.
author: Caro M.

description:
I hate to give bad reviews, but.
What my wife and I did like was our waitress, the beer and the salt and pepper calamari.
What I didn't like was the crepe had very little meat(shrimp,pork)and was very little, two bites each. The sea bass was definitely thawed from frozen. Which really is uncalled for in a city like San Francisco. Last the $100.00 bill. Bummer. I usually don't have a problem spending that kind of money if was worth it.
author: Eric H.

description:
We've been going to this restaurant over several years more than 10 times. 

We tried banxeo, imperial roll, flaming beef, pho, salt and pepper crab, salt and pepper calamari, some salad, etc. All were delicious and never disappointed us. 

The restaurant is cozy with candle & flower. Very nice restaurant.
author: hun y.

description: Order take out.  Everything we had to eat here was great!  However the service was horrible.  The server dropped used chopsticks from another patron on my wife, totally forgot our drink order and had to be reminded 20 min later, but the most upsetting part of the whole experience was not being  informed that the crab special that we ordered was $60 when nothing else in the menu was over $15.  I don't mind paying $60 for an entree if I know that is the cost and its something I really like. I had no idea the special would be that much more than anything else on the menu.  That seems like something a server should mention.
author: C R.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants to go to in SF. The food is very good, the service is great, and the ambiance is very pleasant.

I am far from being an expert on Vietnamese food and I can't say this is super authentic Vietnamese food (maybe this is more Vietnamese/French fusion than some other Vietnamese restaurants), all I know is that every single thing I've ever ordered from this restaurant was delicious. I am a big fan of seafood, and their seafood dishes are yummy. The food always tastes fresh. Some of my favorites are the imperial rolls, the flaming beef and prawns, any of their fried rice dishes, and the prawns with garlic and black pepper. 

It may be because I was raised in Europe and my bf was raised in South America, but we think the timing of the service is perfect. The staff makes sure to bring your food at the right time, in the right order. In my opinion, there is nothing worse than being rushed while you eat. I prefer not getting my appetizers all at once and not getting my main dish when still working on the appetizers. I also don't like when my food is ready in two minutes, so I like that food at La Vie takes at least five minutes to reach my table. The staff is super nice, friendly without being invasive, attentive without being overbearing.  

The ambiance at La Vie is calm, intimate, but not stifling. It's very nice for couples, adults, but I would say it's also good for families as long as kids don't expect a Chuck-E-Cheese's like environment. 

Overall this restaurant has consistently been a great dining experience. If I didn't live on the other side of the city, I'd be there all the time haha...
author: El. C.

description:
Like many restaurants in SF, I felt like it was good, but expensive, and not worth the price.

We really should have tried the crab, but it was so prohibitively expensive, we didn't.  We did try a curry chicken, which was unmemorable.  We did try the flaming beef, which was an exhibit, alright, but I feel like it was 50% more expensive than it should've been just because of the display.

I'd come back sure, but not running to do so.
author: Liz L.

description:
The food was good, but had pretty crappy service.  Worse is that they ripped us off multiple times.

The waiter who served us quoted us $48/crab when we placed the order.  Then, when we got the cheque, they charged us more.  Then, they disputed with us about how the crab should rightly be charged $53-54, because they quoted us wrong.  A few dollars off of a $300+ tab aren't a lot.  I can't believe they had a big dispute with us, when all we wanted was to get the price we were quoted.  Most businesses take responsibility of their own fault for quoting the wrong price.    

One more thing, when we ordered the Vietnamese Crepe, I noticed that they gave less lettuce than I normally get when I ordered it at other Vietnamese restaurants.  So, we asked if we can get more.  They brought it to us without telling us that they would charge extra for it.  They gave us 4 more piece of lettuce that looks like mere garnish and charged us $2 for it.  If we knew we're paying $2 for that, we would have not ordered it.  

Also, when we placed the order, they asked us if we wanted rice.  We said sure.  When the cheque came, they didn't tell us they would charge $1.25 per person for rice when we placed the order.  The menu didn't say so.  There were 9 of us.  Not all of us had rice.  If they told us in advance that it was $1.25 per person, we would have specified how many people wanted rice.  At the end, we paid $12 for 4 bowls of plain white rice.

Also, CRAPPY SERVICE.  They never refilled our waters without me keeping on asking.  One time, after I asked the water 3 times, the waiter even said, "You had a water bottle on your table, so I thought you didn't need any water."  

These people are sketchy about what they charge.  Not a very ethical business.
author: e c.

description:
Good food but not amazing.

Is over priced IMHO, the current service is good before there was a guy that was frequently drunk and sometimes hitting on my gal. Nonetheless funny.

The food is better than others in the area, but I think they use some pre made ingredients such as pre made garlic sauce, etc. The pho is not that great but is not what defines this place.

Is as I say, a good informal place to go to get good food, just thought it is expensive for the level.
author: David W.

description: Wow!  That was some amazing butter garlic crab.  It was so fresh you could watch them fish it out of the tank, literally.  Crab, it's what's for dinner at La Vie.
author: Erin-Leigh D.

description:
The food is tasty, but really what Vietnamese food in the bay area isn't?  

The prices are a little high for most other Vietnamese places in the area but not way out of line.  But I have the feeling I'm getting ripped off because of the unmarked specials on the menu. Don't make the mistake of ordering any of those as they are ridiculously expensive for what you get.  We had a steamed small piece of fish. Nice but nothing special, and not the whole fish, just a small piece - about $30. Ouch. 

The beer and wine prices are not marked on the menu. 

Find out the price of all food before ordering it or you may be unpleasantly surprised.  

Also, we had them split the bill over two different credit cards.  They added a very nice tip for themselves to the bill.  
 
This is the second time I've been to the place and the last.
author: Reginald F.

description:
I would not recommend La Vie.

La Vie opens at 11am.  I ordered 3 items to go at 11:15am.  Guy says to hurry down.

Items ordered:
1) deep fried soft shell crab
2) Beef Phó
3) Shimp & Pork roll (I know, right?  I regretted ordering it soon after I placed the order)

11:30am - I arrive and there is nobody to greet me.  I wait.  I cough. I wait.

11:32am - Through the door leading past the large tank containing multitudes of crabs in slightly green water I can see a man go back and forth in the kitchen, a little quicker than what I would call normal.

11:33am - The man finally notices me and apologizes says that I arrived too quickly.  Evidently the first deep fried crap was over cooked and so they (?) had to start afresh.  He serves me tea.  It tastes burnt.

11:36am - A potential customer comes in the door.

11:38am - The potential customer, having been given no service whatsoever, leaves.

11:40 - Man comes out with food.  Apologizes, saying that the waiter who was suppose to arrive at 11am hasn't come in yet.  The man, who I am beginning to suspect is a very hands-off owner, doesn't know any of the prices and has to inspect the menu.

11:41 - As soon as I'm out the door I open the container holding the crab and nibble.  Tasty?  I think so, but when I'm driving away I try another piece.  Something is not right.

Now, I don't know much about deep friend soft shell crab.  Maybe it is suppose to taste unclean and slightly bitter (chlorinated came to mind). But I drove home pondering the potential clues presented to me: 

a waiter who doesn't show and doesn't call.  a cook who burns his first dish of the day.  no customers (Hong Kong down the street had a line out the door).  no service.  burnt tea.  

11:50 - After throwing the crab away, I dig into the Phò.  Beautiful carmel color.  I take a sip of the broth....and it tastes like water.  Literally, there was no flavor.  Caramel food coloring has more taste.

The shrimp and pork roll was fine.
author: Russell P.

description:
On my quest to find the best restaurants in my neighborhood, me and the boyfriend decided to try this place. We started with the chicken fresh spring rolls. I was suprised that they give you two small spring rolls for $6.95. We also ordered the hot and sour soup for $8.95. I thought the portions would be generous considering the simplicity of these dishes and the price they are asking. The next big blow was the entree. We ordered the garlic buttered crusted catfish with steam rice for $12.95. I swear there were three 2" x 3/4" pieces of fish spread amongst a bed of lettuce! It was like eating small fish sticks dipped in fish sauce and ginger! 

The food was good, but extremely pricey for what you get. I grew up around Vietnamese food in San Jose. I'm used to big bowls of delicious steaming hot Pho for $2.95 to $5.95. Actually, I'm just used to bigger portions at Vietnamese restaurants overall. This restaurant served traditional Vietnamese food with 2 star decor at 5 star prices. I honestly don't think there's any reason for their prices. They had nothing special to offer except for traditional Vietnamese dishes. If they lower their prices, I bet this restaurant would be booming with business.

My 3 star rating is for the place being clean, friendly service, and fresh food.

Very disappointing about the overpricing since I wanted this to be a gem that I frequent in my neighborhood.
author: Liz K.

description:
It's not your regular, $6 bowl o' pho joint. There are real cloth napkins, meaning none of those damned overstuffed stainless steel paper napkin holders, and real flowers in real water on each table. It's very clean and quiet, with a bubbling koi tank at the front entrance. I like when Vietnamese restaurants give shouts out to their French influences with names like La Vie, and an outpouring of that delicious French-press coffee.

Other Yelpers have said this is authentic Vietnamese food; while I can't confirm or deny it, I'll at least say this is very different from any other Vietnamese resto you might use as your lunch standby.

Shrimp and pork steamed rolls were standard and tasty, as always. But we also got coconut curry with chicken and noodles and lemongrass chicken. Both reminded me of better versions of Asian fusion, being vaguely reminiscent of Thai and Chinese dishes. To me, that was both a negative and a positive.

I'd come back if I had a hankering for the well-seasoned noodles, but I'll probably have a hankering for a big bowl of pho or vermicelli before that.

C'est la vie?
author: Tara R.

description: We just had dinner at La Vie. It was  the most unexpected, delightful experience. Four of us had vegetarian spring rolls,  whole Tamarind Crab , Lemon prawns, Garlic Noodles, some sort of fabulous vegetables and  a refreshing Sauvignon Blanc. The food was so good that we were like children scooping up the sauce from the crab platter just by itself! We are jaded foodies. I don't understand why this restaurant is not with lines out the door. This was our first visit, certainly first of many, many more!
author: Yasmine S.

description:
La Vie serves good, traditional Vietnamese food.  At an average of $10/entree, prices are decent.  Thankfully, they have a separate vegetarian menu.  

Decor is modest; tables are candlelit; staff are nicely dressed with coordinating outfits.  The service was great, maybe even bordering on overbearing.  The waiter didn't quite go as far as to put the napkin on my lap and start feeding me.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Fantastic service from our waitress, very reasonable price and excellent food. Exceeded my expectations and then some.
author: Benji L.

description:
La Vie - The Anti-Pho Restaurant

This is this the restaurant to go to, when all others in the neighborhood have a long wait.  NOT that you need to dress up for this place but it's a little more upscale looking than than your typical Pho House.  We're talking tableclothed tables and intimate lighting.

Three Words - BO LUC LAC
Written in the menu and translated to English:  Beef "Look Luck."  Others may call it "Shaking Beef."  Beef lovers, this is your dish.  At 12.95 for the dish, you get a hearty serving of cubed tender beef in a sweetened, soy sauce colored, onion/garlic pepper lime sauce.  I've only been here once but I do get a memory/craving for this dish from time to time.

Negatives
- Many of the dishes listed in the menu are over $10.00.  Come on now!  At an Asian restaurant?  Actually I may have eat my words upon my return - my Shaking Beef was a huge portion and the other dishes could possibly follow suit.
- Scary, this place is usually somewhat empty.  I overheard some regulars saying to the owner, "The food is so good here, we're really surprised that no one is coming in here to eat."  Ya know what?  More for us, yes?

As there is an abundance of good restaurants in the Outer Richmond, I do have to restrain myself from going back to order my BO LUC LAC here.
author: D. A.

description:
Update 2-10-07

I was sent not 1, not 2, but 3 rude, harassing emails from someone who "claims" to have been a "witness" to what happened that night.  Hmmm ... there were 3 people involved in the conversation ... me, my date, and our waitress ... so I'm assuming it was sent by the waitress, one of her friends, or another employee of the restaurant .  The truth hurts sometimes.  They should use the information to improve their service instead of harassing customers.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------



If I could give this place a 0, I would.  My date and I were hoping for a quiet, romantic dinner but instead we left  hungry 1 1/2 hours later, and my date ended up with stomach pains all night. 

First of all, we waited 20 minutes for someone to take our order.  We were 1 of 4 tables with parties of 2 and then there was one large party of 12-14 people.  The 2 people serving food were doting on the large party ... bringing more drinks, etc., but they ignored all the other tables.  No one came by to ask if we needed water or to let us know the food would be coming shortly.  I noticed some of the other small tables getting ancy, we were all exchanging glances like "What the hell is going on?"   One couple, who had been there before we arrived, even got up and walked out.  We were about to do the same but then our appetizer finally arrived ... over 30 minutes later.  

We ordered the Grilled Lemongrass Chicken.  The waitress tossed the chicken around in a pan at our table.  I made a comment about how happy I was that the food had arrived but she was looking over her shoulder at the large party the whole time, and then a minute later she put the chicken on our plates and walked away.  

We rolled the chicken in our crepes and took a bite.  We chewed, we swallowed, and took another bite.  My date said the chicken tasted funny and spit it out.  I held the meat in my mouth while he poked around on the plate.  He made a face and told me to spit it out.  The chicken was uncooked.  We flagged the waitress down and told her the chicken wasn't cooked.  We weren't rude in any way, we expected her to apologize and say she would bring out a new dish ... a cooked one, but instead she said with attitude, "What do you want me to do about it?"  

My date said, "Bring us another dish, this one isn't cooked."  The waitress then said, "Well it's dark in here, I can't see very well."  At this point my date tried not to get upset.  He pointed out that it shouldn't matter whether it was dark or not, that she barely spent anytime cooking it, that we'd been waiting a long time, and that we'd been receiving poor service all evening.  The waitress then started telling us about all the problems in her life and ended with,"How would you like it if you had to deal with all that?"  We listened in bewilderment.  Then she continued to tell us that it was her mother's restaurant and she didn't know what she was supposed to do, etc...    

I then asked her what she expects when she goes out to dinner, what type of service, etc.  She didn't answer but just proceeded to be rude and continue on with her problems.  We told her to cancel the rest of our order and bring the check.  She didn't even offer to remove the chicken dish from the bill.  We had to tell her we weren't paying for it.  

Needless to say, I will NEVER go back there again.

We went to Khan Toke instead (a fabulous restaurant!!!).  We asked for lemon wedges right away to kill any bacteria in our stomachs from the uncooked chicken.  I was fine but my date had stomach pains all night.  (I think he took bigger bites).
author: Miss Purr fec t.

description:
While the food was really tasty, I'll never go back here, which is unfortunate.  On a Saturday night, they were so understaffed that we were there eating for 2.5 hours for 5 dishes.  Here are the other things that will make me not return: 

1. we had 2 kids in our party who were so hungry because of the long wait, I asked if they could give them a bowl of rice.  They charged us for rice for 4 f($6!) -- when we wouldn't have even needed it if we hadn't had to wait 45 minutes for a dish to come out. 

2. garlic noodles? more like a small plate of spaghetti (really, it was spaghetti) doused with butter and some chopped garlic. 

3. we got the roasted crab - very tasty - no price listed on the menu.  I was expecting maybe $35 for the crab.  It was $52 !!!   that's insane. 

There are way too many great restaurants with superb service, fab food, and reasonable prices that I won't be going back to La Vie.
author: leslie y.

description: The pho was unbelievable! Some of the best, but the spring rolls were slightly disappointing. The service was great and the fried bananas were awesome! I will be coming back often!
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Originally my friend and I wanted to go to Pho Garden but they were closed so we decided to give La Vie a try.  It had a nice romantic ambiance, dimmed lights with a rose on each tables.  Service was nice and attentive considering there was only one server for the whole restaurant.  Be warned because service is a little slow dinner will take around two hours.  When I go out I go for the food and it did not meet my expectations.  Vietnamese food is bursting with spices and flavors but at La Vie the food was unsavory.  One word disappointing. 
We ordered 
-Imperial rolls, $9.95. The dish came with a side of romaine lettuce, carrots, rice noodles, herbs, watered down fish sauce and 5 mini thumb size rolls.  The rolls were so small that I could barely get a sense of that they tasted like.  
-Fried calamari, $11.95.  The best dish but the portions were so small.  There were only a handful of calamari accompanied with a side of cabbage and sweet spicy dipping sauce.  The calamari was really crispy on the outside not over cooked inside and it had a nice heat to it.  Did not prefer the dipping sauce, I found that it overpowered the salt and pepper.   
-I ordered the Basil and tomato noodle soup with crap meat and shrimp, $9.95.  I've had this dish at other Vietnamese restaurants and wanted to see how La Vie's would compare.  The soup base was tomato water, completely bland.  Sparse seafood in the dish.  
-Coconut chicken with noodles.  This was my friends dish I asked him what he thought it was good.  
I wouldn't return just because I don't think it was the bang for the buck. Four dishes and no drinks, our total plus tips was a little under $60.
author: Kate M.

description:
If atmosphere matters, don't go here.

I feel I have to state that at the outset because, aside from a nice-size fish tank with some healthy, plump, bored-to-tears koi. How symbolic, as the fish are beautiful and pathetic all at once.

The menu isn't your standard set of vermacelli and pho dishes. But it's not exactly exotic, either. We got a shrimp and pork steamed roll for appetizer, for example.

Our main dishes were a coconut curry with chicken and noodles, and lemongrass chicken. Both tasted good, but not much more than exceptional.

Go here when you're in the area, but I wouldn't make this a destination.
author: Jeff H.

description:
So my mommy and my cousin came to visit me last Sunday to go on a fun little sunset boat cruise in the bay...and as all my fellow San Franciscans can attest...the weather was putting a big fat shizzle on our plans.   So the obvious next plan was to make my mom take me out somewhere I would not normally go. I *really* wanted Vietnamese crab and I know that there is an amazing place in the sunset but I just couldnt remember what it was called! *cries* Driving around, getting hungrier by the second, more and more delirious...i remembered driving past this place while going to shop at One World Market (best russian store in the area fyi). We parked and walked on inside...
the decor is pretty simple, it seems like a traditional Vietnamese place....and i was in the a BIG treat and surprise because both the presentation and the flavor of the food was gourmet!! 
We had...
fried soft shell crab app = super most delicious not fishy and not overly fried. easily a 5 star dish.  
shrimp cup cake = THE MOST AMAZING DELICIOUS THING i have ever eaten. seriously..... imagine a cupcake. Now..cut off the top and scoop a little hole out of the bottom part. Insert delicious whole shrimp. Oh yeah, did I mention the cupcake is made out of some sort of a delicious corn coconut type concoction? On the side..there is a vietnamese salad which is basically fresh large pieces of lettuce, a variety of fresh herbs, and a delicious sauce. I have actually been dreaming about this dish every night since I ate it... super 5 star dish. 

We also had the seafood noodle soup which was...I would say a 3.5 star dish. There was nothing actually wrong with it...it just didnt have that special extra oomph that the other dishes had. Also...it probably didnt help that the guy at the table next to us was eating beef pho, which was my favorite dish in the entire world before I gave up red meat...so maybe  I was just...you know....hating myself at the moment. 

We also had the shrimp hot pot which was....i dunno i would also say about a 3.5....but this is a personal flavor thing. I just wasnt digging the spice blend. 

My cousin had the lemongrass chicken which she said was really good...I did not try as...well..I dont eat chicken. 

I also give this place major bonus points because they have a vegetarian section of the menu which is actually vegetarian, as opposed to dishes in other places like green beans with pork which can be listed as vegetarian. They also have a vegetarian hot and sour soup on the menu which I did not try but desperately want to...

the conclusion? I will be eating here like..at least once a week from now on and I highly recommend you all do as well.
author: Yuliya R.

description:
What a wonderful semi-hidden gem in the Richmond!  The place is not flashy; in fact, it's hardly even noticeable.  From the outside, the place blends in with the other restaurants, nail salons and insurance agencies you will find on Geary Boulevard.  The burgundy awning doesn't exactly scream "come and eat here," but you'd be foolish not to.  

Even the decor isn't much.  It's your basic Chinese/Vietnamese restaurant setup with glass on the tables protecting once white tablecloths.  Add a few traditional gaudy gold/red decorations and a mandatory fish tank, and you've got a pretty good picture of La Vie.

What sets this place apart is the food and the service.  The Luc Lac Beef, or 'shaking beef' as it's sometimes called, is unbelievable.  Soft, tender, juicy and tasty, the beef cubes make for a perfect entree.  I also tried their specialty, La Vie Beef, served with coconut milk and curry sauce.  It was delicious, but I am not a curry fan.  I doubt I'd find anything on their menu better than Luc Lac Beef.  The pepper and salt sauce they serve on the side adds a perfect amount of oomph to the beef.  We also had imperial rolls for our appetizer, which were good but not extraordinary.

Another great attribute of La Vie is the service.  The waiter and the hostess treat you as though you were dining at a 5-star upscale restaurant.  Courteous, helpful and knowledgeable - that describes the waiter at La Vie perfectly.  They refilled our waters repeatedly and replaced our silverware without our asking.  If my memory serves me right, the waiter once told me that he worked at the Ritz Carlton part time.  They wouldn't just hire anyone, you know.

Oh, and the prices are very fair.  The dinner with 3 appetizers, 3 entrees, 1 beer, 1 Thai iced tea and 1 soda cost us $110 including tax and tip.  We were very full and very happy with pretty much everything.

As a big fan of Golden Turtle (that Vietnamese restaurant on Van Ness and Broadway that closed down a couple of years ago), I have to proclaim La Vie my new favorite Vietnamese restaurant.  Try it, you will NOT be disappointed.
author: Yan G.

description:
I think this restaurant is okay but it just ain't my cup of tea.  I'm sure there are others who like it much better and they definitely have their great reasons to.  The food is pretty good.  The value, well, it depends on where you classify this restaurant.  

Some may say, it's a tablecloth place, not your normal Pho place.  So those people are justifying why they have to pay more here.  For those that say the prices ARE good, they are considering this a "Higher Class" Vietnamese restaurant as well and are quite happy with the prices.  

I guess for me, I would rather go to the mom and pop, no atmosphere type of Pho joint and if I was to eat a more "upscale" Vietnamese dinner, I'd probably go somewhere else too.  

It's a Big Mystery for me about this place.  Maybe others feel the same??? Obviously, many people seem to like the food here but many have agreed that it's usually dead in here.  Is there a reason why?    

Maybe it's a Haunted Location and you just don't know why you do not like it......

It's like there's some type of "Supernatural" energy keeping me from here...
author: Mark W.

description:
I gotta give it up to our waiter.  He wasn't much of a conversationalist, but he really did his best to make sure we had a good time.  He tried cracking a few jokes and making some heartfelt suggestions.  It was duly appreciated.

But as for the food, well, when we left we were broke and still hungry.  The beef luc luc was especially tasty, but at fifteen bucks for a lunchtime portion, I have a hard time recommending it.  With the diverse selection of food the outer Richmond offers, I'd say visit La Vie if you're in the mood for something different.  Otherwise, give something else a try.
author: Tony L.

description: My friend Courtney C. and her fam have been coming here for years.  We had some fresh spring rolls that tasted, really, quite fresh.  So fresh and so clean.  We had soft shell crab that I didn't eat because I don't love crab, but everyone else at my table (many diff generations) loved it.  For my main dish, I got a peanut curry vegetable and braised bean cake stir-fry and I loved it!  I think a place that can do good meat and vegetarian gets a lot of points.  Our server was a young woman who was friendly and on top of her game.  I liked the no nonsense decor and quick service.  Definitely another Richmond fave.  Honestly, I think the Richmond would be paradise if you could subtract the fog/cold.
author: Julia D.

description:
While many restaurants come and go along the Geary Blvd corridor, La Vie quietly manages to thrive in the Outer Richmond serving a community with family-style friendliness while increasing a mums-the-word clientele. Though open for both lunch and dinner, to get the full experience, best to go for dinner. The vegetarian Imperial Rolls with stuffed Shiitake mushroom (Cha Giao Chay) is a wonderful starter. Can't go wrong with sweet-n-sour soup here. For Entrees any carnivore is easily satisfied with the Bo Luc Lac in black pepper & lime juice sauce. People rave about the crab and garlic noodles but it's the Sea Bass in black bean sauce that creates a memory. For lunch, try anything in a clay pot.

Warm, inviting little family-run operation.
author: Johnny C.

description:
I've been very hesitant to write my review for La Vie as it is my favorite Vietnamese place here in the city.  Why?  Because I love the fact that it's a hidden gem.  Not raving about it though is doing this phenomenal place a huge disservice, so...

I absolutely love this place, and I will always choose it over places like Slanted Door.  Wonderful flavors and so true to Vietnamese cuisine.  While they do not serve pho, here you will find other classic dishes that you would not normally see on a Vietnamese menu, like banh xeo, a Vietnamese-style crepe.  The classic shaking bo luc lac (shaking beef) is melt-in-your-mouth-tender and so nicely complimented by the salt-pepper-lime sauce.  The garlic crusted catfish was devoured, and if we could have licked the plate discreetly, we would have.  The service is outstanding, so friendly.  The owner and staff will remember you and your favorites, which is always a warm fuzzy feeling.  They even have a delicious dessert menu beyond the 3-bean drinks, which is uncommon for most Vietnamese restaurants.

The only downside is that it is in the outer Richmond so parking is horrible, but the #38 and #1 drop you off pretty much at the door.
author: D k.

description:
Okay, I know that the Italians take their sweet time with things, and when I go to an Italian restaurant I expect to be in it for the long haul. I didn't expect the service at a Vietnamese restaurant to make Eeore look like he has a spring in his step and could win the 100 yard dash blindfolded. Slow is an understatement! 

So, now that I have set the precedence for how much time you need to devote to a quick bite to eat, I will say that the food was good. I am not sure if it was because I was starving by the time I got it, but it seemed like the dishes were tastier than many I have had in other Vietnamese places around town. The prices were a little higher but well worth it. Added bonus was that it felt more like a restaurant than a cafeteria, which is the general feeling I get from most of the Vietnamese retaurants in the Richmond. 

If I have a ton of time to kill some evening in the future I might pop in here again.
author: Drue C.

description:
There are very few places that are as consistent as La Vie is in the quality of food and service.  The service is always consistently mediocre, but the food more than makes up for it.  The staff are friendly, but just a bit spacey and lethargic.  For a Vietnamese restaurant, the prices are higher than places you would find in San Jose or in the tenderloin, but the quality of the food here is far superior.  I have eaten at many Vietnamese restaurants ranging from totally ghetto (tiny sandwich shops) to extremely overrated and overpriced (the slanted door, La Chinois, and Ana Mandara) but La Vie continues to be one of my favorites for several reasons.

1) there is almost never a wait here so it's a good place to go if you have a large group 

2) it is always quiet so you can hold conversations

3) the food is superb- I recommend the Bo Luc Lac (shaken beef) and the garlic noodles.  They also have excellent crab dishes here.  (the waitress once recommended the La Vie crab special but I didn't like it as much as the garlic butter crab they serve)

The only thing that sucks about going here is that it's kinda far from everything and parking is a total nightmare.  Other than that, this place has a special place in my heart because it always reminds me of home.
author: Jade L.

description:
A really nice-looking place you can bring your mom to and they don't overcook the vegetables.

Don't bring Steve J. to La Vie because I'll order the roast crab, and Steve J. won't have any of it because he won't eat any seafood, least of all a dish that looks like a giant sea spider. But, they tend to bring out the crab first and the rest of the dishes 20 minutes later.

So, I'm cracking and picking and eating the giant sea spider, and Steve J. just leans on a hand, waiting for his La Vie Chicken.

But, when the food comes out, eventually, it is delicious.
author: Stacy J.

description:
Service:  Mediocre, On a Sunday afternoon, with a half-full floor, there was only one waitress (the daughter of the chef) who rushed back-and-forth from the kitchen to the dining area somewhat frantically. 
Food:  Barely Acceptable:  1) the grilled pork skewers were half-blackened from the char-grill.  When we pointed this out, the waitress blandly replied: "It's actually pork, and we make sure its cooked through."  2) the spicy lemon-grass noodles (stir-fried) had a strand of wire (yes, metal wire) mixed in.  When one of the persons found this and brought it to the waitress' attention, she dismissively replied: "Oh that's just from the strainer that's used to cook the noodles" (as if metal wire in your food is acceptable food service).  
As an aside, there was no offer to comp any of the dishes.  While the food was barely passable, as long as you keep your eyes open for offending contaminants, I will not return to this food establishment - ever.
author: Tim Y.

description: First time I went here a few years ago it was pretty good.  Had the Vietnamese crepe which was good and the crab heavily seasoned but still good.  Service was good.  They were really nice.  Both times I came the place only had a few customers.  I tried it again recently and had the calamari which was only ok and the La Vie Combo imperial rolls, grilled prawn and bbq beef or pork served with steam noodle, rice paper, lettuce mint and basil.  The rice paper was a bit off smelling a bit weird  but couldnt put my finger on it.  When I took a bite of my roll with the grilled shrimp it did not taste fresh at all.  That pretty much did it for me.  Maybe they are just very hit and miss...not consistent.  I wont be coming back.
author: she q.

description: I just went back to this place after moving away from the city.  So nice to see that the quality has not gone down.  It is a great place to go.  I particularly loved the roasted crab.  This place will give you the "whole" crab, meaning they will serve you more than crab legs.  I often wonder what the other restaurants do with the most delicious part of the crab... which are inside the shell, not the legs.  When I saw that in this place, I was sold!!  It is a delicious combination to eat them with their garlic noodle!
author: Amy K.

description: This place is great!  They have awesome vegetarian pho with vegetarian broth (which can sometimes be hard to find)!  The veggie pho comes with tofu and veggies and is simply delicious.  It also has a lovely ambience - really relaxing and chill.  A great place to come on a foggy or rainy evening.  Definitely check this place out!
author: Mary Beth M.

description:
I really enjoy dining at La Vie.  Great place to go if you want to have a nice Vietnamese meal with friends and want to have some good elbow room and engaging  conversation without having to yell, raise your voice, or scoot your chair (or body) when your table neighbors come & go.  It's not overly crowded or crammed with tables, and definitely not a hot 'scene' type of restaurant.  Very mellow and low key but complete with crispy white table cloths and fresh flowers.

I have had a good amount of solid and delish Vietnamese plates here.  Love the roasted crab dish.  The garlic noodles have been somewhat of a disappointment lately but I hope they improve it.  The only dish I did not care for was their mango chicken - sauce was way too sugary sweet.  But everything else has been good.  Excellent service too.

Parking can be tough in this area but after circling the block a few times, you can opt for the valet service on the corner (Aziza).
author: Cat K.

description: Everything we had was fabulous.  The Vietnamese croquettes were delicious, with crunchy rice around them.  The pho was scented with cinnamon, which made it extra-special.  The clay pot was so tasty, and the rice had caramelized all around the bottom.  This is a wonderful place to visit.
author: Lolailo Y.

description:
Excellent meal here.  The food tasted great (chicken salad, bbq pork skewers, eggplant with garilic or something), was presented beautifully, came quickly, and was a good deal. What stood out though was the service and the restaurant itself. This is the kind of place that replaces your plates between the appetizer and main course, is on top of your beverage throughout the meal (and brings out the replacements in a separate little pouring glass), and so on. Place was totally clean. There were even candles and flowers. It kinda felt like an actual date night or something - I barely know what that's like anymore. But hey. Gotta give them props for that.  We'll go back. 

Oh yeah, and we had the sticky rice dessert (kiwi and green tea sauce). That was pretty awesome.
author: Jen D.
