description: Great restaurant. with great food and a great team.  The crab is amzazing.  La View ranks as one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.
author: M. F.

description:
Places like La Vie make me nostalgic of my many years in the Richmond District.  It's a bit fancier than some Vietnamese joints.  Really makes for a relaxed atmosphere.  

We dined here last Friday night and, sadly, the place was deserted except for another couple.  I loved the fact of their 100 rating from the health department displayed in the window.  I get squeamish easily.  The service was slow despite being empty and the wait staff not overwhelming helpful or memorable.  Not bad service but nothing to write home about either.

I first ate at La Vie 10 years ago.  This was my second visit.  It was memorable the first time and I would definitely return after my most recent visit.  I had the noodle bowl with pork and imperial rolls.  The flavors were fresh and clean.  The serving was generous and it was priced nicely at $8.95.  

My food partner in crime polished off what I didn't eat.  He ordered some variation of pho.  I sampled the broth and it was rich.  I'm not a Pho or Vietnamese food expert by any means, but it seemed less "clean" tasting than other Vietnamese fare I've sampled.  Still tasty.

We agreed it definitely warrants a return visit.  The crab special priced at $48 definitely does not warrant a try.  I don't care what the raves are --  that's way too much for any dish.
author: Liz P.

description:
Cute little Vietnamese place that has never disappointed.  Service has always been extremely friendly when I've been (a little freaky that they can  sometimes remember what I ordered MONTHS ago, but whatevs).  Wish they delivered, but they do have carry out and quite a large selection of menu items to choose from.  I think my favorite could be one of their spicy noodle soups!

Update: Had my first dinner here tonight with friends.  We were pretty much the only people there, but I suppose at 7p on a Wednesday in the 'hood that may not be too uncommon.  Again with the SUPER great staff (she remembered me from past lunch visits and welcomed me to the dinner service).  The La Vie crab with garlic noodles is pretty much everything it's cracked up to be.  De-effin-licious!  Along with the Chef's recommendations of coconut infused pork and shiitake  and beef (with a generous helping of Bo Luc Lac from the menu) there was really nothing else I could have asked for.  All of the dishes were truly excellent.  So yeah... was a 4 star, now a sparkling 5 star.  Great place.  Promise!
author: Jason M.

description:
This is an intimate Vietnamese bistro -- they are good for lunch with excellent pho, but they are superb for dinner. Roast crab, bo lok luc, coconut infused pork, it has all been superb. 

Service is excellent, decor is unassuming. Highly recommend.
author: Andrew A.

description:
A Vietnamese restaurant that is not high-end that serves meat that is "Western quality?"

Yes!

(HIGH quality meat in their dishes! Love it!)
author: Katie B.

description:
I grew up around the neighborhood and always thought this place too much for my pockets. This place is amazing good and prices are a little bit on the high end. A party of 2 people we spent $60 pp.

We ordered the Garlic peppered crab which comes with a side of garlic noodles. They serve this to us first and didn't serve anything else until we finished it. This crab is SUPER good. I would highly recommend the crab here. I'm a big crab fan.

Beef Lok luck a.k.a shaken beef. Not the best I had but had really good flavor and goes really well with rice.

Lemongrass chicken was regular and nothing special. 

Overall I would return and try the other crab flavors. This place isn't usually busy but parking of course is always hell here.
author: G C.

description:
ahhh la vie. i've driven past you many many times on geary but just assumed you were another tasteless vietnamese spot. how i was proved wrong! so my friend recommend i try shaking beef in the city bc he had been eating it every day (almost) in NY and i trust his opinion. he found la vie via yelp for me and told me, "GO HERE. NOW. EAT IT. AND TELL ME HOW IT IS."

so one rainy, stormy night, i took his cousin to la vie for dinner. we decided on the  bo luc lac (shaking beef), raw beef sald with shrimp ships, and scallop dish with vegetables. OH MY GOD. AMAZING. so the salad came out first and it was raw beef with cilantro, onions, nuoc mam drizzled over the whole thing and some other stuff. but the best part was the shrimp chips. we scooped the raw beef salad on top of the shrimp chips and they "sizzled" similar to pop rocks. yes. i am easily amused. 

the scallops were tasty and the vegetables were tasty too! soft and not super hard. (hahaha) the shaking beef came with a little thing of pepper sauce on the side and the beef was tender and not tough. i'm thinking about it right now.

the only thing is, service is slow. there weren't many other diners there with us, so i don't know why it took a while for them to notice we were done. usually i wouldn't care but i was on a time crunch that night.

either way, i'll be back!
author: Melanie C.

description:
yummy Vietnamese food.  Very tasty.  The calamari with bamboo was done very well - tender squid and fresh tasting.  The cat fish in the clay pot was also good - but the brown sweet sauce seemed to be the same as used on the bbq pork.  The brown sweet sauce is delicious so I didn't mind it so much - but it seems to be ubiquitous.

Service is wonderful - very prompt and friendly.  We went out with a bunch of girls and we closed down the restaurant.
author: Madison W.

description: small, but exceptional service! the raw beef salad is sooooo GOOD! garlic noodles... I prefer thanh long. crab is just as good though!
author: Ann T.

description:
this tops the list of abosulte MUST HAVE whenever friends visit...

yes, there's great french food in SF, there's great italian and american and fusion places to eat... but i garantee the only thing most people never had until they visit san francisco is the fantastic, meaty, humongous dungeness crab that is so famous here...

enter La Vie. 

this is a very unassuming restaurant and one might walk past it and miss it. the inside is a long corridor with square 4-tops on each side and room for 4-top table running the length of the place... you wouldn't think this was a fancy resturant from the looks of it - it's very down to earth and modest.

so, onto the food - the appertizer fried tomato beef in spring rolls is a MUST!
what they do is put the raw beef and tomato, red onions, cilantro and a delicious sauce in a big white bowl that sits on a plate.. then they light the liquid that's on the plate and the waiter cooks the food right in front of you as the flames run orange and blue on the plate all around the bowl. it is mesmerizing to watch and smell the food cooking right at your table side. they give you the spring roll wrappers to assemble your own which adds fun to the meal (very impressive to show your date, boys!)

--------------------------------------------

ok, now let's get to the heart of La Vie - their La Vie Roast Crab is their specialty - hands down. the crab meat tasted like the crab was born infused with garlic and cilantro...!
they take some of the crab roe and with some ground pork, eggs and a bunch of other spices, stir fry it all up and then present it under the crab shell and unveiled when served...
the crab comes with 'garlic noodles' which is spaghetti noodles (as supposed to asian style noodles at some other crab places) - ask for white rice instead, i find that the crab being so flavorful, you need more of a blank canvas to showcase the contrast ...

you know you are a good friend when i take you to La Vie - there is not any ladylike, graceful way to devour crab meat.. your hands, arms, face smeared with crab shells and meat and that, to me, defines great crab...

--------------------------------------------

La Vie has always been consistent - the roast crab ALWAYS taste delicious. I am impressed that it is consistently top notch!!!! the service is great, very friendly, professional... they come and change out plates in the middle of the crab meal, they bring the water-lemon bowls for your hands, and they are attentive without being stalkerish. 

this place is a well deserved 5 stars, i wish they would open another restauarnt  closer to san jose!!! writing this review makes me crave the roast crab all over again...
author: amy c.

description:
So, I desperately wanted to love this place. I love Vietnamese food and this restaurant is only a few blocks from my house. I've been there three times, twice for dinner and once for lunch. The lunch was great. We sat at a small table near the kitchen and the service was impeccable and the food was delicious. I was thrilled & couldn't wait to return. 

However, the next two times I returned, I could not have been more disappointed. While their food was good, it wasn't great, and the service I received both times was horrendous. I went once with my fiance and then another time (thinking the other experience was a fluke) with another couple. Both times, they NEVER checked back on our table after our food was delivered. We had empty drinks and wanted to order dessert, but were flat-out ignored by the staff. There were two servers and only 6 tables, hardly a busy night. We practically had to jump up and wave our arms to get anyone's attention. As a former waitress/bartender, I err on the side of tipping too heavily, but I had to go to 10%, which I actually felt was quite generous given their inattention. 

They have a cool aquarium in the front, and really above average food, but I recommend take-out if you're going to stop by La Vie.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Pro: Great food, tried the Bo Look Luck (bo lok luc) - great flavor; crab - the spices are just right!; basil seafood - spicy, yummy
Okay: chicken wrap (rice wrap) - kind of bland; hot tea - weak
Con: Parking, absent of service when asked for possible parking location.
author: Eileen B.

description:
I remembered it being a lot better before.  I ordered somethings to go today and somehow it didn't taste as good as before.  The bo luc lac was a lot more peppery than I remembered.  But its still one of my faves...altho I have tried my own version of it.  Ha I guess I got pretty close.  My friend ordered the garlic noodles the beef in aromatic "lot" leaf.  It smelled really good but he didn't share so I didn't get to taste.  

Well if I ever get to go back and try them again I might give them one more star.  Old favorites were the flaming beef and prawns (I believe they cook it at your table and used rubbing alcohol to cook), the hot and sour soup, and the lemon grass combo.  Hopefully when I go back it will taste as good as they used to be.
author: Allison T.

description: My co workers and I were very excited to finally try this place, especially with allthe raves and reviews. I really didn't find anything that amazes me. I was hoping atleast the garlic noodles would blow my mind away, but it was too much pepper . Soooo it was just okay!!
author: Tess C.

description:
Should have listened to my gut and not walked into an empty restaurant, but it was 9 at night and we were hungry. Anyway, I'll keep it short and sweet. 

Food was acceptable, but overpriced for what it was. 

Wine was bad. Tasted like it had been opened about a week earlier and sat in the fridge ever since. Really $9 a glass for that? WAAAAY overpriced.

Service was fine. Unmemorable really. They could have really made a positive impression on us considering we were the only customers in the whole restaurant, but whatever.

I would have given it 3 stars except the staff decided that it was an appropriate time to clean the fish tank. The fish tank that was about 8 feet from where we were sitting. And eating. We really didn't need to see all that ummm.... material being kicked up by the scrubbing while we're eating your mediocre food. Bad decision.

No need to ever go back to La Vie.
author: Pete C.

description: This is one of the best meals I've ever had, i loved the calamari, roll-your-own-summer rolls, the roasted crabs with garlic noodles and rice and the fried ice cream
author: Nicole R.

description: La Vie Roast Crab is the best-tasting crab dish in San Francisco.
author: M R.

description:
Love the food-Love the service.
My husband cannot eat gluten.  This can be a problem because soy sauce contains wheat. This eliminates most Asian cuisine. Unfortunately I do not know the name of our server but she has been consistently helpful.  She recommends dishes without gluten or has them prepared with a different sauce or a rice based flour rather then wheat.  
Never once have I found we sacrificed taste!  Another great feature-they have the option of brown rice and they have a delicious blend.

We also have members of the family who are vegan-again La Vie is a great option.  Many dishes can be prepared without meat or seafood and they are always flavorful.

Some favorites:  Crab meat and asparagus soup-Vietnamese crepe-veggie steam rolls-lemon chicken.
author: Rose G.

description:
So I made a Yelp account just to post this. 

I've been to this place before, and generally have thought that the food and atmosphere are pretty good, but tonight I was extremely disappointed by the service of this restaurant. We were given menus and the server encouraged us to get the crab special, which under price had the word "seasonal" but nothing else. Now, my friend and I are poor graduate students, and we meant to inquire into the price of this dish, but forgot to do so. Needless to say when we got a bill that charged us $50 for ONE crab we felt taken advantage of. Especially because of his insistence that we buy it. Now, after some research we understand that crab can be expensive, but the least they could have done was to have the courtesy to inform us of the price of this dish. If the price isn't stated on the menu, and is subject to fluctuations as the server explained to us, I feel that a restaurant who valued their customers would inform them of the price of such a dish. We both feel like we were played for suckers by this, and it put a sour note on the end of an otherwise enjoyable evening. 

This incident has marred my opinion of this restaurant, and I do not think I will ever dine here again. 

BUYER BEWARE!
author: Christopher H.

description: I'm at a lost for words, tomato basil pho was amazing, the coconut noodles were amazing, this place is probably the best pho you can get in SF, and it gets my first 5-star rating. It's a great place for a date too, they dim the lights, play soft music, and they also have an affordable selection of wine. Parking was brutal on V-day though.
author: Nathaniel C.

description: I used to go here with friends in high school. I would always get the pho, though they do have rice dishes and noodles. The pho is OK though I prefer the Pho Hoa one on Irving and the chain. And the rice dishes we had weren't all that good, especially the chicken, which was dry and not very grilled.
author: Petra S.

description:
We ended up here last night for a late night meal after being turned away by the Dim Sum place across the street.  It's got a nice evening ambiance and is great for couples or groups of 4.  I really liked the 33 beer, which has a unique aftertaste and is a great addition to the menu.  We started with the La Vie sampler, which is a couple skewers and a chance to create your own rice paper rolls.  Lots of fun, and extremely tasty.  Then it was the asparagus and crab soup - kind of plain, but good as well.  We ended up going with the coconut curry crab for an entree, and in addition to a great king crab it came with some delicious glass noodles with a sweet curry paste underneath.  

The appetizers, soup, main course, and service were all 5 stars, so why am I knocking off one?  First reason is the garlic noodles, which taste exactly like my ex used to make.  Not that they were bad, but they came with most of the crab dishes and just felt out of place.  Other is the price - $50 for a crab?  Yes it was fabulous, but can't say I'd make a habit of it.  This is definitely going to be a favorite dinner spot, though.
author: John H.

description:
La Vie is literally a couple of blocks away from my house. I probably walk by it twice a week. That being said, I happened to Yelp it, and see what other people are saying about the place. Seeing that most people liked it, the husband and I decided to try it.

We started off with Beef that was wrapped in grape leaves. It came with lettuce leaves, rice noodles, mint, and bean sprouts. Very tasty indeed. Then we ordered the garlic noodles. They were ok, but I was surprised at how little we got. It was really only enough for one person on what looked like a salad plate. I guess I am used to another vietnamese restaurant around the corner where they gave you a whole bowl of garlic noodles. But so far, everything was good.

Then, we also ordered a whole crab. I know that the price said, "market price", but again, I guess I was comparing it to the other vietnamese restaurant around the corner. Honestly, I was flabbergasted that the crab that we ate ended up being $48 - just for the crab! And it wasn't even the best crab we ever had. So for our 3 food items, 2 lemon sodas, plus tip, the meal was almost $100! Now, I'll pay good money for good food, but for two people, not expecting it at all, well, that is just ridiculous!

Yes, this place is a nice restaurant. White table cloths, that's for sure. The staff was incredibly nice, always filling my water glass and checking on us to see if we were ok. But I almost threw everything up when I saw the bill. Unfortunately, I will not be coming back to La Vie unless I go with a friend who has an abundant amount of cash.
author: Jan Z.

description:
An excellent excellent excellent dining experience every time.

Well-worth the bus/drive out west.  The interior is nothing fancy, but it's surprisingly cozy.  The dim lighting would probably make me a little sleepy if not for the startlingly strong Vietnamese coffee (hot) that I can rarely resist.  This coffee's got kick, you may want to steer clear if you plan to sleep within the following five hours.  It's also possible that I'm just extremely sensitive to caffeine.

Moving on.  The food is perfect.  The meat is indeed high-quality, tender and flavorful.  The sauces are excellent complements, and sometimes pack as much kick as the coffee.  

The pho is very tasty, but you can get great pho all over SF, so I tend to go with other dishes unless it's a super cold night.  I highly recommend the beef luc loc.  I'm not sure I had ever had this dish before La Vie, and it's already a list-topper.  

I have not yet tried the crab, but I regularly see them being delivered in 2's and 3's to other tables, and am usually jealous.  The jealously, however, tends to last only as long as it takes me to rediscover the delicious feast on my own table.  

Yep, well-priced, well-prepared, and the servers are super-friendly.  La Vie deserves every point of these 5 stars.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Went there on a Sunday.  Food was really good.  

Parking was a problem though.  We arrived about 7ish.  It was difficult to find parking, as everyone was apparently thinking the same thing we were.  

They are somewhat slow to serve you.  If you expect immediate acknowledgment or service then I might suggest bypassing here.  Other than that the food was good and the atmosphere was pleasant.
author: Soh Jai R.

description:
I debated 3 or 4 stars for La Vie bec/ it has to be one of the sleepiest, low-key neighborhood establishments, ever. If you live in the city, you want to walk out the door and find a selection of at least 3 excellent dining choices. La Vie should be one of these. The problem is I feel drowsy immediately upon walking in, and without the assistance of supremely stimulating company (which I was lucky to have both times), it's game over. The decor, service, lighting, hushed tones?  zzzzzzz.  

Barring that, I can highly recommend the flaming beef and shrimp wrap appetizer, crepe appetizer, and La Vie Chicken. Wonderful. The beef and shrimp actual come out in a bowl that is set on fire. It sizzles. Satisfaction. Your typical Vietnamese restaurant won't charge half as much, but those places tend to execute a whole lot of sandwiches and noodles (which are fantastic in and of themselves), or a number of dishes that taste disturbingly Chinese. La Vie is a place for a hot sit down meal with complex dishes, fresh accompaniments (mint, basil, limes, cucumbers, sprouts, chilies), and a flavor distinctively from Indochina. I'd say it was the judicious application and intelligent blending of ngoc mum (fish sauce) with lime.

So I ended up with 4 stars bec/ the food, and everything else, is consistent. The best part is, if you do live in the area, you always have a place to go, and can walk off some of the discomfort post-dinner bec/ you gorged yourself. (I was told the weather in SF is consistently spectacular.)
author: Conifers J.

description:
Yummmmmmyyy... I ordered the Beef Prawn, Crab, String Beans, and Beef cubes. 

So delicious. A perfect place for a group of friends or a date.  I am coming back here again....fo sho
author: Mike L.

description:
I have been going here since I was a kid and I can tell you it has only gotten better.  When I moved to the midwest La Vie was the first place I wanted to go when I came home to SF.  I love the food here so much.  My personal favorite is the flamming beef with prawns appetizer.  It is so delicious and there is the added advantage of having flames sitting next to you at the table.  Their salt and pepper squid ...yum.  Their soups are amazing.  Basically it is all great.  

Man! Now I am hungry.  I might have to make a trip out to the richmond because it is sooo worth it.
author: Cork C.

description:
I will echo all the positive reviews here and say that La Vie is a great Vietnamese spot. Their specially prepared crab is pricey but worth it for a nice meal. The service is solid and you get the sense they aim to please.  

If you live in the Richmond, you have no excuse not to try La Vie!
author: Yana C.

description: Walked in late night, starving after a 12 hour day. The hostess Sylvia was very kind, and helped me select the right dish. I was so indecisive! I loooved her selection, couldn't have been better! I'll certainly make this a regular stop. Thank You!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Although not a total disappointment, we left here feeling less than satisfied.  For starters, we asked if we could get the lemongrass chicken "not spicy" and the waiter said "sure".  But once it arrived, it was as if they made it "extra" spicy.  I love spicy foods but my kids don't - they couldn't even touch it, and it was almost too much for me.  Also felt they were a bit over priced for what you got.  There are certainly better Vietnamese restaurants in the area, which is where we will go next time. 

Oh, and don't get me started on the 11.2 ounce beers... really? For $4.25 I would really expect at LEAST 12 ounces... I felt ripped off there too... whatever.. the food is good, but not great.  Tasty, but it doesn't explode in your mouth with flavor.
author: Steve W.

description: Pho great, 5 Spice chicken the best, try it its almost like roast duck. avoid the beef, overdone & poor quality meat.
author: Cgl N.

description:
Up until last week I had only stolen leftovers from a friend's fridge - cold bo luc lac yum!

Although the cold leftovers are delicious I'd have to say eating here was a much better experience. I had something from the special menu and it had TONS of scallops - no skimping here. A table across the way from mine had something flaming and the waiter periodically come over to stir it...not sure what it was but I'm ordering in next time.  Good service and good food - yup another yummy place in my hood!
author: Lauren D.

description:
Order the Vietnamese Crepe...I think it's made with coconut milk , rice flour- and pan fried, one reason why I think they are crispy and so delicate...shrimp, chicken and other delights are added...beautifully golden in color from a pinch of turmeric...fresh mint , bean sprouts on the side... and Nuoc Cham! I love Nuoc Cham! Who cares that my rings won't fit the next morning and my eyes get puffy from all the salty fish sauce? It's worth it.

Get the Shrimp Cup-Cakes. Yup, that's right,  I said cup cakes. (Banh Khot?)...savory (not at all sweet), petite coconut custards that are "fried," creating a crisp outer shell...they really do look like little cup-cakes topped with a single juicy shrimp..each bite melts in your mouth. They are traditional, but I've only recently discovered them...more Nuoc Cham.

Crab. La Vien Style. Roasted....
How about Curry Coconut Crab stuffed with Glass Noodles and Macadamia Nuts? Traditional my foot. La Vie can be innovative without completely losing their heads.

Lemon Grass Beef, Steamed Bass, Clay-pot Catfish , Eggplant Coconut Curry are all winners....

The service is elegant and professional...they prepare some dishes table-side. Another charming addition is that all the tables have fresh flowers, a pastime I still appreciate.

The wine list is decent and paired well with the Vietnamese menu.

Of course, parking sucks.

The only minor glitch was the Koi fish tank at the entrance, all stuffed in a tiny tank swimming around like crazy....One fish kept playing with a marble and it went "rat a tap tap" throughout our entire meal...They could have used some plant life in that tank, and maybe less fish, bigger tank...Koi don't like sudden movements or shadows...placing their tank near the door seemed a bit cruel and disturbing. (hope I don't sound too self righteous)-EFK
author: Eliza K.

description: After reading numerous reviews my friend and I decided to try La Vie, which I've passed many times over the years and never tried.  The spring rolls were fresh, reasonably priced, and came with yummy peanut sauce.  For entrees, we had the La Vie chicken, which was pretty good.  However, the garlic noodles tasted like spaghetti with minced garlic.  It didn't taste bad, but it certainly didn't seem like an authentic Vietnamese dish -  more like Sunday night leftovers.  As warned, the service was very slow.  The ambiance was nice, which is a nice change over most Asian places in the Outer Richmond.
author: Carrie R.

description: I fell in love with Pho at this restaurant so it will always have a special place in my heart. It is the perfect meal on a foggy day in the city. Also, their rice dessert is amazingly fresh.
author: Will U.

description: Horrible food, horrible service, and horrible smell. Take your money elsewhere, like to Thanh Long or PPQ.
author: Joe B.

description: I love La VIe. Inexpensive, tasty, beautiful presentation. The flaming beef bowl really impressed my visiting parents.
author: Favorite G.

description: There is nothing better than some the pan fried noodles at la vie. I also just love their apps and the prices are kinda high but not as much as thanh long.
author: Nadia N.

description:
decent food albiet little meat in the dishes

very slow service

tablecloths need to be changed...

not sure about this place. my last trip was my third or fourth and it may be the last.
author: Mr G.

description: This was my first time trying Pho and I was so pleasantly surprised! I loved La Vie the moment I walked in because of the white table clothes and super cute ambiance. What a great date place! We had spring rolls, chicken pho and beef pho. The place was very quiet with great service. If we weren't already stuffed from the giant bowls, we would have picked something from there long delicious looking dessert menu as well. And everything under $30?! I will be back for sure!
author: Dawnn M.

description: My sister worked with Vie at her old job and she took us here to check out his restaurant. The food was great and so was the service. From the outside it is very unassuming and I would have never stopped in randomly if I wasn't taken here or already knew about it. Don't be fooled, the quality of food is great and Vie and his staff are super friendly.
author: Ryan S.

description: This place has a nice ambience. It is ok. The chicken pho is an ok version good broth but hardly any chicken in it and the chicken that was there was tough. I had a cherimoya shake to drink which was yummy. The big let down was the garlic noodles! Really bland and not at all like the delicious garlic noodles many other spots. Do not order them The staff here are very nice and the flaming beef prawn is quite tasty
author: Pez B.

description:
My boyfriend introduced me to this place about one year ago and I have been addicted since.  We were in Asia for a few weeks and this was the ONLY restaurant we craved when we came back!  I've been to many Vietnamese restaurants and maybe cuz I'm Vietnamese, I've always been extremely picky about them.  I've tried Thanh Long - overpriced, waaaay too much MSG and oily and the worst is, the last time I had their roasted crab, it came out COLD.  Same thoughts on Crustacean's.  As for PPQ, it's good if you're on a serious budget and you're just looking for an average meal.  We've taken many family members and friends here and everyone has had a unanimous positive experience.  La Vie gets 5 stars for the following:

Service - friendly staff that actually SERVES you with a smile and doesn't give you attitude when you ask for anything.  Where and when was the last time you actually had great service at an Asian restaurant???
Atmosphere - lighting is not too dim or too bright.  The patrons that frequent this restaurant have the common courtesy to turn their cell phones to vibrate mode so as not to disturb your quiet meal.  The ambiance is conducive to a nice romantic dinner for two or a quiet dinner with friends where you can actually have a conversation and actually hear each other!
Cleanliness - Sanitation has always been almost completely absent in most Asian restaurants, but this place is very clean.
Price - for what you get, it's going to be a bit more pricey than PPQ, but still way more affordable than Thanh Long and Crustaceans.
Food - The best way to rate any Vietnamese restaurant is by how authentic their flavors are, especially in their Nuoc Mam (fish sauce).  This place makes an almost perfect concoction of the sauce without compromising the authenticity at all.  I hate it when Vietnamese restaurants give you phony fish sauce!  
**Our favorite appetizer here is the Flaming Beef and Prawns.  It's served in a porcelain bowl, cooked at your table side.  The flavors really complement each other very nicely.  You can't come here and NOT order this.  The favorite dish is of course, the La Vie Roast Crab.  They take the insides of the shell and stir fry it to perfection.  The dish also comes with garlic noodles.  There are other great dishes too, but these two are our favorites.  If you go with just one other person, the appetizer along with the crab will be enough for the both of you.

The only thing I do not like about this place is the location.  Parking usually is pretty horrible here.  The longest time I've ever had to circle around for a parking space is was almost an hour.
author: Selene K.

description: I'm quite surprised that there are no reviews for this restaurant yet.  Its a modest, low profile little vietnamese bistro with pleasant decor, excellent service and great food.  We shared the Bo Nhung Dam which is a beef fondue simmered in a vinegar, lemon grass and ginger broth served with rice, lettuce, mint leaves and plum sauce and they make it tableside.  oooh special treat!!!
author: Rick H.

description: Ok so I have been to this restaurant many times and I would rate the food as a 4 star. I am writing this review with two stars to let fellow Yelpers know that my last experience was not very good. the food was still good but the service was BAD BAD BAD! Only two servers who tried hard but did not cut it. There were six of us dining on a Saturday night at 6:30pm so it was busy. I would expect an Asian food restaurant that serves good food to be busy at 6:30 on Saturday night! I would think the ownership/management would expect this also. Last time I visited (Wednesday) it was not very busy but they had two servers that night as well. The folks around us were visibly annoyed, one table near us threatened to leave and another table did leave. When our dinner was finished we all wanted desert but raher than ask us about our interest in desert the bill showed up. We asked and were told that the owners were going on vacation the next day so there would be no desert! HUH? What the heck? Anyway when we opened the bill the tip 20% had already been added. Party of six... Arrrgh!
author: John L.

description: I tried this place aftering seeing reviews in Yelp. It was a sunday at 1pm and there not a soul in the place but myself. I ordered two appetizers and was fairly disappointed. I had these crispy croquettes made of minced pork/fish cake.. it was crispy but really underwhelming, and only made better using the plum sause for dipping. The other appetizer was highly recommended, was the shrimp cupcake, these were shrimp placed on top of mini muffin or cup cakes hallowed out in the middle, it seemed like some kind of corn meal cup cake, there were six small cupcakes and shrimp that came and a side salad to compliment.. Overall i was not impressed, the flavors were too subtle, bland and the two appetizers without drink came to $27, a bit high for lunch..
author: Jim W.

description: I love this place, but the only problem is that the food takes too long! The service is great and i love the la vie crab! If you go there, you MUST get the la vie crab!
author: Lin L.

description: There are a few Vietnamese places in the Richmond - this one is my favorite.  Great place to take a date due to the quiet ambiance.  I am usually doing take out which also works out very well. My favorite dishes are the Beef Look Luck ( Bo Luc Lac), BBQ Pork, and any of the fried rice dishes (beef, shrimp etc).  For apps, I usually get one of the rolls (shrimp, chicken, pork).
author: Scott B.

description: Food is great, but price is kind of high. So we only go on special occasions now...=(
author: Cathy N.

description: I love this place. Best fried rice. Best pho. Best crab. The service is outstanding. I should try more things, but the pho is so good I get the same thing every time. The only thing I would change is the beer selection...four or five beers that all taste the same.
author: Biff A.

description: A little pricey for what you get. The garlic noodles were decent as was the bo luc lac (shaking beef) but it was a small portion for the amount they charged. Perhaps I should try their other offerings, like the lemongrass chicken. But until then, a disappointing experience.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
c'est La Vie! after a 5-year hiatus, i returned to this old haunt last friday for a celebratory meal with friends. at first, i was a bit worried that the much transformed interior - formerly bright lights and modest decor to present day dim lighting and tasteful wall art - also meant a change in the quality of food. the best way to make a determination, i decided, was to order my absolute favorite dish: the La Vie roasted crab. 

i may have idealized that dish all these absent years, but i did feel like there may have been a wee bit degradation in the quality of the crab dish. but if indeed there was any degradation, it was quite minute. the dish was still very, very splendid. and for my friends, who were trying it for the first time, the dish was out-of-this-world. it is a must-have.

we also dined on tradiational hot and sour soup, sauteed veggies over chilled rice noodles, and lemongrass beef  - all of which were so delicious that there was not a morsel left. for dessert, we had the fried bananas with ice cream which was standard and the sweet sticky rice with kiwi which was wonderful. 

the service was excellent AND they spoke vietnamese which is always a plus. 

all i know is, i am not letting such a long time elapse before i return. after all, la vie is too short!
author: Baochi N.

description: never seem to make it out to this part of the city but that is going to change because of this cute lil restaurant.  Recently ate here for the first time and I really enjoyed the delicious crab, attentive waiter and cute ambiance.  Great reason to head down Geary and grab a great dinner at an even better price.
author: Johnnie T.

description: 3.5 stars. The place was empty except for us on a Thursday night at 8pm. Service was pretty quick, although my partner was served his entree and then a few minutes later mine came. I had chicken curry, which was pretty good with a big portion. He had beef noodle soup and he said it was a bit better than average. Smaller portion but tasty. We would return here, but we aren't running.
author: Bing B.

description: Parking is a little difficult, but not too bad. It's a tiny restaurant, but it's clean. The food is good, I'll admit, but the waiters are sooooooooo sloooooooow. But nice waiters =)
author: Lucky N.

description: The food is really good (but i've had a couple dishes better elsewhere for less).  I wouldn't order the usual imperial rolls and bbq pork over rice that i love oh- so- much...they have much better things on their menu...u can tell they use really fresh ingredients.  Great presentation and the service is top quality for a fairly priced restaurant.
author: Steph S.

description: My boyfriend actually found this place when he was walking home one day. He suggested we try it, and I was down to go. At first we were afraid that it wasn't open because no one was in the restaurant. But to our surprise it was open and welcoming customers. We started off with the calamari. The appetizer was full of flavor. Not to mention a little on the spicy side. Whatever the seasoning was I kept wanting more. For our entree we decided on one of the chef's special, mango and prawns, and the Look Luck steak. Both were excellent choices. The chef's special was sweet and savory, and the beef dish was cooked to perfection. Let's just say we were not shy about finishing both dishes. I am looking forward to going back and trying other things on the menu.
author: Cortney H.

description: I have come here for over 10 years and it is the best Vietnamese restaurant I have ever eaten at.  Period.  Fabulous raw beef salad.  The best fried calamari in town.  Flaming beef and prawns served with rice paper.  I now live clear across town, but will come here before any place else, Slanted Door included.  Nice professional wait staff and very good service.
author: Holly B.

description: We went on a Thursday night.  Took about five mintues to find a parking spot on Geary.  Food was light, tasty and high-quality.  Good beer and wine selection.  Relaxed, simple, upscale somewhat romantic atmosphere in the restaurant.
author: J. O.

description: Food is great and so is the service.  Not particularly a fancy or trendy restaurant, but to be honest they sure treat you like that's what they want to be!  There is always something interesting on the special menu, it's not usually crowded, and you can linger over a nice meal here.
author: Ken B.

description: Empty for Sunday lunch (everyone was in line at the dim sum place across the street, but we were too hungry to wait). We split a hot and sour soup - nothing like the usual heavy Chinese stuff - a delectable broth filled with fresh vegetables and prawns. Also shared croquettes - deliciously hot and crispy on the outside, and delectable on the inside - and lemongrass beef, washed down with Vietnamese beer. Service was good, bordering on too-friendly (it's a thin line, ain't it?).
author: Mi M.

description:
everything we had was delish! most notably for me was the egg's nest with the crispy noodles ... it was to die for. other big hits at our table were the vietnamese croquettes, the crab, and the hot and sour soup. and the desserts? ... definitely save room. i think we ordered a majority of the desserts offered and they all were outstanding (the fried banana w/ice cream, and the deep fried ice cream, and the sticky rice with kiwi, and and and!!).

this is a family owned and operated restaurant. the chef/owner was as sweet as can be and the service was excellent.
author: cynthia q.

description: Excellent Vietnamese food in an upscale restaurant (tablecloths and cloth napkins) means higher prices, but the quality and service warrants that.  A bit stiff for my taste, but may appeal to folks looking for fancy.  When it was a block away, we thought it was the best pho in SF, but it's too far for me now.
author: Esther R.

description: Sweet Jesus, who knew that garlic crab could be sooooooo amazing.  I kid you not the crab is the size of your head and possibly the best thing you have ever tasted!@!
author: Nicole F.

description:
a friend and i wanted to get food after a night of drinking and soup sounded good. he lives down the street from here and had been here once. the inside is clean, not like other pho houses i've been to. no oily, sticky tables. no large aluminum containers with hundreds of plastic chopsticks. no mini spinning trays with large mucked up sauce bottles. very impressive for a french infused vietnamese restaurant.

customer service was nice and recommended the calamari for appetizer when asked. the menu and pricing was just above a deal. little bit pricey on the seafood, but the flavor backed it up. they had a wide selection of new dishes mixed with a touch of original vietnamese style dishes. of course we didn't get to try them since we just wanted some pho noodle soup. which was interesting because they didn't have that on the menu. he just asked what kind of meats or tendon we wanted in it. nice, get what you ask for type of place. 

i asked for meat combination with tendon. my friend just wanted beef. we also asked for some hot tea to start with. he came back with some great jasmine tea, which i had before at the sf airport, but can't remember the brand. 

a moment later we were served the calamari. this stuff we couldn't stop eating. very strong herbal flavor; slight touch of mint. served with a lightly spiced sweet chili sauce which you dripped over the calamari. crunchy and delicate; it wasn't chewy. we ate everything and still picking up crumbs off he plate.

then soup came out along with the sauces which were in small serving jars and a plate of fresh bean sprouts, basil, and jalapenos. the soup was very warm just as i like it. as always i take a couple of scoops of the soup with no sauce or adding basil. it tasted great. just full of flavor. then i flavored it up and cleaned the whole bowl(including soup) which i rarely do. give this place a try when your in the area (geary & 23rd? i think) hit the spot!
author: Rob D.

description: Im allergic to sefood so cant say much about the crab. My cousin said it was just okay, shes had better. The bo luc lac was one of the best I hve ever had, and the rare beef salad is the best I have ever had. The garlic noodles were okay, nothing to write home about. The noodles seemed like a concoction that I could throw together at home. Service was excellent. i will definitely be back.
author: Beach L.

description: This restaurant is simply amazing.  I love all the fresh herbs, spices and ingredients used to prepare the delectable entrees served here.  I always leave this restaurant completely satisfied and wishing I had a bigger stomach so I can eat more.  But even if I overeat, I always justify it with the fact that the ingredients are not only healthy but fresh and good for you. It's a win win when you come to this restaurant.  Try it for yourself.
author: Aech2 O.

description: This restaurant isn't as expensive as it looks . It is still affordable . What impressed me most about this place was the Flaming Beef And Prawn . They actually make it in front of you . They put the dish on fire and everything !! So cool haha ! It's also very very delicious . I forgot what else I ordered but the garlic noodles were not good .
author: Eileen L.

description:
i had never eaten the underside of a crab's shell because it's disgusting, however i did once recently for the sake of not wasting my mom's spent money here. it was good for being  the guts of a crab but i'll never have to eat it again. i can say i've tried it and i'm done! 

the rest of the food was good. i wouldn't say amazing. however there was a dish in which they lit a plate on fire to cook the beef for our rolls. entertaining for sure. taste-wise it was not much different from other vietnamese restaurants.
author: Regina C.

description: got the beef pho. the broth was delicious. couldn't stop eating (or drinking?) it. the beef was meh. the atmosphere was unexpectedly romantic. overall, i liked it. in fact, i came back three days later.
author: Jackie C.

description:
This is our family spot.  My entire family LOVES dining here.  I swear we come here for everyone's bdays every year.  

5stars for ambiance, service, & food.  A little on the pricer side but totally worth it.  Their rice paper rolls, crepes, crab, veggie dishes, & BBQ dishes are delicious.  We get them every single time. ;D

NEG- Richmond district parking SUCKS.
author: renee t.

description: This is by all time one of the best French Vietnamese restaurants in S.F.  The Bo Luc Lac (shaken beef) and La Vie Crab is so flavorfull and yummy. Everyone that I bring there have gone back and always enjoy their experiences at La Vie. The staff at La Vie are friendly, attentive, and helpful.
author: Samantha P.

description:
This is the perfect place to have a roasted crab! i've been here about 5 times and each time I've received excellent service and each time I've enjoyed their Special Roasted Crab. The seasoning is unlike any other I've had. They mixed the excess stuffing from the shell with special seasonings, which adds to your entree. One crab is enough for two people, with an additional entree'. I've also tried their no shell prawns and special soup, which are both delicious! The servers are attentive and friendly. The restaurant is clean and peaceful. It's a hidden gem!

Cons: Parking- but if you don't want to search for street parking, there's a lot on the corner, about 1 block away.
author: Jae L.

description:
My wife and I've been here a few times over the years, and it's usually pretty good. It's a little fancier than the typical Vietnamese restaurants we go to, but the ambiance and service are usually worth it.

However, we went back recently with mixed results. Here's the good, bad and the ugly.

Good
The eggplant dish (was it garlic eggplant?) was one of the best Asian eggplant dishes I've ever had. And I've ordered eggplant at so many freakin' places that I feel like an eggplant expert by now. La Vie, I bow before your greatness -- it was that good!!!

The Bad (though not that bad)
Ginger Chicken with Ear Mush (see note below to find out what Ear Mush is) was actually pretty good except my wife didn't like the tiny ginger slivers; she thought it should've been cut bigger to make it easy to pick out. I thought the dish was pretty good but not as good as the eggplant.

As for Ear Mush, we think they meant to say Ear Mushroom. But their typo was cool; made us laugh. When we went to China years ago as tourists, we saw quite a few funny signs in English. Those signs are getting more and more rare (sigh...) as they gear up for the Olympics.

The Ugly (but not super ugly)
We've been here a few times over the last few years, and until recently the service has always been very good. I mean, if you're charging a bit more, the service should be good, right? Well the last time we went, the service just wasn't up to snuff. I mean, we were surprised at the lack of service. Maybe it was an off night, I don't know. 

Bottom line: It's been a consistently good place for slightly upscale Vietnamese food, and we'd go back. Hopefully service will be back to normal next time. It's one of my favorites for Vietnamese.
author: William S.

description:
these guys have been favorites for a long time.

tableclothes, flowers on the table and soft light - but i go in wearing motorcycle boots & jeans - & they so don't care.

* pho contains extra marrow makes it really really good. available all the time but you won't see it on the evening menu - you have to ask. they have a vegetarian option.
* look luck beef - best i've ever had. anybody remember the golden turtle? this place is just as good.
* lollipop shrimp - v.good
* softshell crab - v. good
* sizzling rice soup - weak broth/good
* catfish claypot - very good

order the vietnamese coffee & see if they bring a thermos to your table too. so very ridiculous.

love this place.
author: Lawrence K.

description: Absolutely the best crab ever.  The La Vie Crab is off the charts great.  The garlic noodle was good too.  This place is so much better than Crustacean.  My friends and I tried the La Vie and Tamrind Crab.  The stuff inside the shell is stir fried with some eggs and spices and is so rich and delicious.
author: Jeremy C.

description: CREDIT CARD FRAUD! Beware of eating at this place. Just went to dinner there last night and got overcharged on my debit card. I called them to rectify the discrepancy, but was hung-up on mid-conversation. I'm now dealing with it through my bank, but I'd never go back to this place again. The service was only so-so anyway, which is too bad because the food was rather good actually..
author: Steven G.

description: I have brought several people to this place and it knocks their socks off everytime.  Two different people that I have brought here tried the crab and said it was the best they have had in their entire lives!  They were both over 40 and world traveled.  They have their special crab menu and the crab with the garlic butter sauce and the "La Vie" crab were the one's that received the high praise.  And don't miss their calamari appetizer! It's unlike any calamari you've ever tried.  Keep up the great work guys!!
author: John c.

description:
Really not impressed.
Meal was $60 for two, food was mediocre at best, service was meh.
Would have given it three stars for mediocrity, but its being overpriced took another star.
There are MUCH better Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood, just as nice inside and a much better value.
Give this one a miss.
author: Luke K.

description:
This place is a great neighborhood joint. Looove the la vie roast crab, which I have had a half-dozen or so times; when I took my brother here we joked that they must put crack in it or something.  or garlic butter/spicing that works as well.   I've had something similar involving lobster at a chinese vietnamese place down in socal but this is just better. 

The other items on the menu can be stellar too. The appetizers that are flame-grilled table side; the shaking beef, even the salt and pepper calimari is a standout. The noodle dishes are a bit more ordinary, though you should really get an extra garlic noodle order with the crab.

A couple of quibbles: this place is not cheap; there are less expensive places to get crab (i'm told PPQ on Clement). But those crab dishes don't contain the delish spicing/crack. Also, the wines we've gotten haven't been very good.  They let me bring my own wine last time but I'm not sure if that's a rule or an exception.

Still the la vie roast crab makes it worth five stars.
author: P.J. P.

description: The first few times I've had dinner here, the food, service, ambience all made for a pleasant dining experience. But the last time I went, I had  reservation for a large party and even though it was early in the evening and the space was not crowded, our table was not set up. In fact, the host had people in our group set up the table along with them. The server seemed distracted and service ended up being spotty. The food is still good, but it seems like portions are smaller than they have been in the past. I'm hoping our last visit was a fluke, cause I really do enjoy the food, especially the presentation of the flaming beef.
author: chip n. c.

description: Neighborhood restaurant with great prices, friendly staff and good quality Vietnamese staples.  I often crave the beef pho and the croquettes...good stuff!
author: e j.

description: It's easy to find Thai, Japanese and Chinese in the city, but I found Vietnamese to be the tricky asian delicacy of the bunch.  That is, until Saturday night at La Vie.  This very accomodating restaurant (we grew from a group of 3 to a group of 8 on a crowded night without any complaints from the staff), boasts a pretty extensive menu of delights.  Since we were a large crowd we had the luxury of ordering many tasty dishes each one as good as the next.  Try the beef with coconut/peanut sauce or the crispy noodle with seafood (which may be my favorite--light and filled with yummy sea creatures).  Another highlight was the sweet and sour soup, if you are a pineapple fan then this is your soup.  I think they deliver, too.  Fingers crossed that they will travel to the mid haight!
author: Howard G.

description: why go all the way to the outer Richmond district on a rainy, blustery evening, you might ask? for hidden gems like this place. my sis & her husband (i'd like to see THEIR reviews of places since they eat out pretty often) have been here a half dozen times and recommended it. i'm surprised no one on Yelp's reviewed it as of yet. the service is particularly attentive and friendly and the food is pretty outstanding.  the one lone complaint i have is that the appetizer, a spicy salt 'n peppery calamari, cost more than any of our entrees. it was better than expected,  i just don't think that it should cost $4 more than any other entree listed on the menu. my ginger chicken with tree-ear mushrooms was nice and ginger-y and i appreciated that they constantly re-filled my passionfruit ice tea. they have a wide selection of entrees, as well, even for vegetarians.
author: Chris C.

description: The food is delicious, but don't go here if you're in a hurry.  My husband and I went to La Vie on Friday, February 9, for an early dinner (it was about 6:30 PM).  There was only one other customer in the restaurant, and someone took our order right away, but we had to wait a long time (at least 20 minutes) for our drunken quail appetizer.  It didn't disappoint, and we looked forward to our entrees and enjoyed each other's company for another 20 minutes.  I had a shrimp dish (can't remember which) that had a slightly oversweet sauce.  My husband fared better with the lemongrass seafood combo.  Once we were finished, it was again another 15-20 minutes before we could flag someone down for the check.
author: Babs J.

description: My favorite restaurant so far in the ctiy - clean, nice atmosphere (nothing fancy, but nice enough for special occasions), very attentive and friendly service, and most of all, the best French-influenced Vietnamese cuisine I ever had anywhere (beats Le Cheval, Ana Mandara and Slanted Door anytime).  Their bu-loc-loc (shaking beef), bird nest noodle , black bean manila clams, and flaming beef and prawns with wraps (appetizer) are excellent.  I heard the roasted garlic crab is to die for, but I can't eat any because I'll literally die (I'm severely allergic to crab).  Just parking is a drag and sometimes their service can be kind of slow, so beware.  Also, not the best place for kids (although I take my kids and they welcome them) because it's really quiet atmosphere, you feel bad if they get out of hand.
author: Catherine P.

description: Friendly, cozy and delicious. I can see how others might have recieved meager service as the place always seems to be understaffed. I have had the fortune of only being there when it was slow and had nothing but great service. Don't heed the other review, I spent 6 months in Laos and Vietnem and the is the best lemongrass chicken I hav ever had.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Food is always delicious here and the service is always very good.  They are on top of everything.  The restaurant is very simple no fancy decorating stuff.  The quality of food is way better than Crustaceans or Thanh Long.  If you like fresh crabs this is the place to go.  Also, one must try the Flaming Beef appetizer, amazing!  Garlic noodle and the dessert are all done so perfectly too.  The downside of this place is parking it can be pretty bad during dinner hours on weekends...but it's definitely worth circling around for.
author: Wendy W.

description: Delish!!! Best fried banana in SF- coconut icecream to die for. Lemon grass chicken - mmmmmmmm mmmmmmmmmmmmmm,  33 beer- yay!
author: Kylz R.

description: I've eaten at La Vie probably 100 times over the years, and it is one of the better Vietnamese restaurants in the city.  The food is light, fresh and delicious.  I've always found the service to be courteous, friendly and efficient.  Some dishes are prepared tableside so it can be a bit slow if you have a large group.  I love the flaming beef and prawn, catfish in clay pot, combination sea food soup, and the lotus rootlet salad.  It's also a great place for pho soup at lunchtime.  The atmosphere is pleasant, it's not too loud, and I highly recommend trying it.
author: greatbig w.

description: Used to be a great place few years ago, but on our last visit anything that could go wrong did.  Garlic noodles turned out to be plain noodles sprinkled with garlic powder.  Rice paper rolls were so chewy we could not eat them.  The waiter said the cook forgot to soften the rice paper in hot water - but they still charged for them.  One of the waiters spoke no English, another spilled water on one of us - and not a  sign of regret, not an offer to make up somehow.  They had some decent entrees as well, but in general - big disappointment.  I also think they are overpriced for the kind of food and service they offer.
author: Izrail B.
